organizations.name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration
organizations.description: Since President Eisenhower signed the National Aeronautics and Space Act in 1958, NASA has piloted American space exploration and aeronautics research. The agency's early breakthroughs included Alan Shepard's 1961 suborbital flight and John Glenn's Earth orbit. The agency's early years were marked by rapid progress, including Alan Shepard's suborbital flight in 1961 and John Glenn's Earth orbit in 1962. NASA's crowning achievement of the 1960s was the Apollo program, which culminated in the historic Moon landings, beginning with Apollo 11 in 1969. The program, employing approximately 400,000 Americans, cost $28 billion at the time (equivalent to more than $280 billion today) and represented a milestone of human progress. Following the Apollo era, NASA shifted focus to the Space Shuttle program, which operated from 1981 to 2011. During its 30-year run, the program completed 135 missions, with 133 successes and 2 tragic failures (Challenger and Columbia). In recent years, NASA has launched missions such as the Curiosity and Perseverance rovers on Mars, and the James Webb Space Telescope. The agency's current focus includes the Artemis program.

projects.title: Project Artemis
projects.description: NASA's Artemis program aims to return humans to the Moon and establish a long-term presence there.

images.caption: Artistic rendition of NASA's Artemis program
James Webb Space Telescope with its sunshield. Credits: NASA

featuredContent.title: Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL)
featuredContent.description: JPL is a NASA field center located in Pasadena, California, that specializes in robotic exploration of the solar system. It has been responsible for numerous missions, including the Mars Exploration Rovers, Curiosity rover, and the Voyager missions to the outer planets.

images.caption: Image for Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL)
images.credit: Image courtesy of National Aeronautics and Space Administration

featuredContent.title: Artemis Program
featuredContent.description: The Artemis program is NASA's current effort to return humans to the Moon, with the goal of establishing a sustainable presence on the lunar surface and eventually sending astronauts to Mars. It involves the development of new launch vehicles, spacecraft, and lunar landers. Shown here is a rendering of the project. NASA is targeting September 2025 for Artemis II, the first crewed Artemis mission around the Moon. Artemis III is slated for September 2026.

images.caption: Image for Artemis Program
images.credit: Image courtesy of National Aeronautics and Space Administration

featuredContent.title: Mars Exploration Rover
featuredContent.description: NASA's Mars Exploration Program has been a long-running effort to study the Red Planet through a series of robotic missions, including orbiters, landers, and rovers. Notable missions include the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, the Curiosity rover, and the Mars 2020 rover. Shown here is the Mars Exploration Rover.

images.caption: Image for Mars Exploration Program
images.credit: Image courtesy of National Aeronautics and Space Administration

organizations.name: SpaceX
organizations.description: SpaceX designs, manufactures, and launches rockets and spacecraft, primarily focusing on providing transportation services to orbit. The company has pioneered reusable rocket technology with its Falcon 9 rocket and is developing the fully reusable Starship system. SpaceX collaborates with NASA through the Commercial Crew Program to transport astronauts to the International Space Station and through Commercial Resupply Services to deliver cargo. The company’s long-term goal is to enable human life on Mars by developing its Starship vehicle, designed to transport crew and cargo to the Red Planet.

organizations.name: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency
organizations.description: DARPA doesn't just develop weapons; it aims to invent the future of warfare. As the research arm of the U.S. Department of Defense, DARPA pursues high-risk, high-reward technologies that often seem like science fiction. DARPA funds projects across a spectrum of scientific and engineering disciplines, from breakthroughs in AI and robotics to hypersonic flight and next-generation materials. In the 1960s, its ARPANET emerged as the first operational packet-switching network, laying the foundation for today's global internet infrastructure. In the 1990s, DARPA funded research that led to the concept of telepresence surgery, allowing surgeons to operate remotely on patients in dangerous or inaccessible locations. Intuitive Surgical's da Vinci system was built upon earlier DARPA-funded research. The agency bridges the gap between fundamental research and practical military applications.

images.credit: Image courtesy of Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency

featuredContent.title: ARPANET
featuredContent.description: ARPANET, launched in 1969, was the first operational packet-switching network and laid the foundation for the modern internet. It was a pioneering project that demonstrated the feasibility of interconnecting computer networks.

images.caption: Image for ARPANET
images.credit: Image courtesy of Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency

featuredContent.title: Surgical robotics
featuredContent.description: DARPA, working with partner SRI International, helped lay the groundwork for the boom in surgical robotics by supporting research into technologies such as the TraumaPod, a surgical robotics system that would operate on fallen soldiers on the battlefield. This innovative project was initiated in the early 2000s, with the first phase of research successfully completed in 2006.

images.caption: Trauma Pod
images.credit: Image courtesy of Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency

organizations.name: Rocket Lab
organizations.description: Rocket Lab is building a complete suite of technologies for the future of space exploration and commerce. While its Electron rocket continues to provide reliable rides to orbit, the company is developing the heavy-lift Neutron rocket, designed to carry up to 13,000 kg to low Earth orbit, with capabilities extending to lunar missions (2,000 kg) and interplanetary destinations like Mars or Venus (1,500 kg). The company is expanding its spacecraft offerings with the Photon platform to support a variety of missions, from Earth observation to deep-space exploration, as demonstrated by missions like CAPSTONE to the Moon. Rocket Lab is also building solar power systems for spacecraft through its SolAero Technologies division and developing flight and ground software. As a vertically integrated space company, Rocket Lab manufactures most components and subsystems in-house, with their technology having flown on over 1,700 missions globally.

projects.title: Electron Rocket
projects.description: The Electron is Rocket Lab's lightweight and cost-effective orbital launch vehicle designed to deliver small satellites to low Earth orbit. It is the first fully carbon composite orbital launch vehicle and has successfully launched numerous commercial and government payloads since its inaugural flight in 2017. The Electron rocket has played a significant role in enabling access to space for small satellite operators.

projects.title: Neutron Rocket
projects.description: The Neutron is Rocket Lab's upcoming reusable launch vehicle designed for larger payloads and more frequent launches. It is intended to provide a more cost-effective and flexible solution for delivering constellations of satellites to various orbits. The Neutron rocket is expected to have a reusable first stage and is being developed to support Rocket Lab's growing launch manifest.

projects.title: Photon Satellite Platform
projects.description: The Photon is Rocket Lab's satellite platform designed for hosting payloads and providing end-to-end mission services. It can be tailored for various applications, including Earth observation, communications, and technology demonstrations. The Photon platform leverages Rocket Lab's Electron rocket for launch and has been used for several missions.

featuredContent.title: Electron Rocket
featuredContent.description: Rocket Lab's Electron rocket is a small launch vehicle designed to provide frequent and affordable access to orbit for small satellites. It has successfully completed over 50 missions, demonstrating its reliability and capability.

featuredContent.title: Neutron Rocket
featuredContent.description: Rocket Lab is developing the Neutron rocket, a reusable heavy-lift launch vehicle capable of carrying payloads of up to 13 tons to orbit and even interplanetary destinations. This rocket will significantly expand Rocket Lab's launch capabilities.

featuredContent.title: Photon Spacecraft Platform
featuredContent.description: Rocket Lab's Photon platform is a versatile spacecraft designed to support various missions, including Earth observation and deep-space exploration. It can be customized with different payloads and propulsion systems to meet specific mission requirements.

organizations.name: Blue Origin
organizations.description: Space transportation company Blue Origin operates a vertically integrated complex near Van Horn, Texas, where manufacturing, launch, and refurbishment facilities sit within a nine-mile radius. Founded by Jeff Bezos, the company's New Shepard system achieves 99% reusability of components, including its booster, capsule, and engine, designed for suborbital research and tourism. Its BE-4 engine, running on liquid natural gas, powers Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket and ULA's Vulcan, while the smaller BE-3 and BE-7 engines serve different mission profiles. The company's Blue Alchemist technology transforms lunar regolith into solar cells and transmission wire at 99.999% silicon purity without Earth materials or chemical waste. Blue Origin develops systems for in-situ resource use and cargo delivery through its lunar initiatives by way of the Blue Moon lander.

projects.title: New Glenn
projects.description: New Glenn is Blue Origin's upcoming reusable orbital launch vehicle designed to carry payloads and humans to Earth orbit and beyond. It is a two-stage rocket with a reusable first stage and an expendable second stage, capable of carrying up to 45 metric tons to low Earth orbit.

projects.title: New Shepard
projects.description: New Shepard is Blue Origin's reusable suborbital launch vehicle designed for space tourism. It consists of a crew capsule and a rocket booster that can be vertically landed and reused. The vehicle has successfully completed several uncrewed test flights and is expected to begin carrying passengers in the near future.

projects.title: Blue Moon
projects.description: Blue Moon is a proposed lunar lander being developed by Blue Origin for NASA's Artemis program. It is designed to deliver payloads and potentially humans to the lunar surface, with the goal of establishing a sustained presence on the Moon.

featuredContent.title: New Shepard Reusable Launch Vehicle
featuredContent.description: Blue Origin's New Shepard is a reusable suborbital rocket system designed for space tourism and scientific research payloads. It has successfully completed multiple flights.

images.caption: Image for New Shepard Reusable Launch Vehicle

featuredContent.title: Blue Moon Lunar Lander
featuredContent.description: Blue Origin is developing a lunar lander called Blue Moon, which is designed to deliver payloads and potentially humans to the lunar surface. This project aims to support NASA's Artemis program and future lunar exploration missions.

images.caption: Image for Blue Moon Lunar Lander

organizations.name: European Space Agency
organizations.description: The European Space Agency (ESA) unites 22 nations in a shared pursuit: to explore the cosmos and push the boundaries of human understanding. With a network of laboratories, including the Columbus module on the International Space Station, ESA scientists conduct research across a multitude of disciplines, from observing our own planet to probing the mysteries of the Moon, Mars, and beyond. ESA develops novel technologies for telecommunications, Earth observation, and space exploration. One of its most notable recent achievements is the successful launch and operation of the Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (JUICE) mission in April 2023, which aims to study Jupiter and three of its largest moons — Ganymede, Callisto, and Europa.

projects.title: Rosetta Mission
projects.description: The Rosetta mission was a pioneering space exploration mission conducted by the European Space Agency to study the comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. Launched in 2004, the spacecraft rendezvoused with the comet in 2014 and deployed a lander called Philae onto its surface, marking the first time a spacecraft landed on a comet nucleus.

projects.title: Gaia Mission
projects.description: The Gaia mission is an ambitious space observatory launched by the European Space Agency in 2013 to create the most precise 3D map of the Milky Way galaxy. It aims to map the positions, motions, and other properties of over a billion stars, providing unprecedented insights into the structure, formation, and evolution of our galaxy.

projects.title: ExoMars Program
projects.description: ExoMars is a joint program between the European Space Agency and the Russian space agency Roscosmos, aimed at investigating the Martian environment and searching for signs of past or present life on Mars. It consists of two missions, the first of which successfully placed the Trace Gas Orbiter around Mars in 2016, while the second mission plans to deliver a rover to the Martian surface in the future.

featuredContent.title: European Space Research and Technology Centre (ESTEC)
featuredContent.description: ESTEC is ESA's largest establishment and the technical heart of the agency. It is responsible for developing and managing the European space program, including spacecraft design, testing, and operations.

images.caption: Image for European Space Research and Technology Centre (ESTEC)
images.credit: Image courtesy of European Space Agency

featuredContent.title: Rosetta Mission
featuredContent.description: The Rosetta mission was a pioneering endeavor that successfully landed a robotic probe on a comet for the first time in history. It studied the comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko from orbit and on the surface, providing invaluable insights into the early solar system.

images.caption: Image for Rosetta Mission
images.credit: Image courtesy of European Space Agency

featuredContent.title: Copernicus Program
featuredContent.description: The Copernicus program is a joint initiative between ESA and the European Union, providing Earth observation data and services to monitor the environment, support civil security, and enable sustainable development.

images.caption: Image for Copernicus Program
images.credit: Image courtesy of European Space Agency

organizations.name: Lockheed Martin
organizations.description: With annual research investments exceeding $1.5 billion, Lockheed Martin's Technology Laboratories investigate defense and aerospace applications across multiple fields. The labs focus on autonomous systems and robotics designed for challenging environments, with projects including AI-enabled aircraft inspection and physics-based sensor development. Current work includes directed energy weapons, developing laser systems up to 500 kW for military use, notably the 300 kW Valkyrie system for the Army. The company maintains academic partnerships studying quantum information processing techniques. Research activities are coordinated through the 50,000-square-foot Center for Innovation ('The Lighthouse') in Suffolk, Virginia, which houses work on cyber infrastructure, malware analysis, and human-machine integration.

projects.title: F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter
projects.description: The F-35 Lightning II is a family of single-seat, single-engine, all-weather stealth multirole combat aircraft developed and produced by Lockheed Martin. It is intended to perform ground attack, reconnaissance, and air defense missions. The F-35 has been described as the most expensive military weapons system in history, with a projected total cost of over $1.5 trillion for the entire program.

images.caption: Image for F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter
Image for F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter

projects.title: Orion Multi-Purpose Crew Vehicle
projects.description: The Orion Multi-Purpose Crew Vehicle is a spacecraft designed by Lockheed Martin for NASA's Artemis program, which aims to return humans to the Moon and eventually explore Mars. Orion is designed to carry astronauts to space, provide emergency abort capability, sustain the crew during space travel, and provide safe re-entry from deep space.

images.caption: Image for Orion Multi-Purpose Crew Vehicle

projects.title: Hubble Space Telescope
projects.description: The Hubble Space Telescope, launched in 1990, is a space telescope that has made groundbreaking discoveries in astronomy. Lockheed Martin was the prime contractor for the design, development, and construction of the telescope, which has revolutionized our understanding of the universe.

featuredContent.title: Advanced Technology Laboratories
featuredContent.description: Specialized facilities where Lockheed Martin engineers and scientists pursue breakthroughs in fields like autonomy, robotics, and artificial intelligence.

featuredContent.title: Lockheed Martin Successfully Tests Advanced Off-Board Electronic Warfare System on MH-60R Helicopter
featuredContent.description: Lockheed Martin has conducted the first integration test of its Advanced Off-Board Electronic Warfare (AOEW) system on an MH-60R helicopter platform. The AOEW system, described as one of the most complex electronic warfare systems ever developed, is designed to enhance the U.S. Navy's signal intelligence and defense capabilities against anti-ship missile threats.

featuredContent.title: Machine Learning Applications
featuredContent.description: Lockheed Martin is exploring machine learning for various defense and aerospace applications. Here, the company's Missiles and Fire Control's Advanced Rapid Integration Simulation Environment (ARISE), a suite of integrated toolkits developed by Lockheed Martin Missiles and Fire Control (MFC) for creating system-level weapon simulations, also known as digital twins.

organizations.name: Boeing
organizations.description: 'With research facilities across the globe, Boeing develops technologies for aviation, space exploration, and defense. Boeing's Research & Technology division focuses on sustainability, autonomy, and technologies to enhance safety, efficiency, and environmental impact in air and space travel. The company maintains a global network of research centers and university collaborations, fostering breakthroughs across multiple disciplines. Boeing is exploring hydrogen and hybrid-electric aircraft concepts, addressing technical challenges and market viability. In 2023, the ecoDemonstrator program evaluated 19 technologies on a 777–200ER, including sustainable components made from recycled carbon fiber and bio-based resin. A new Boeing Research & Technology Center in Japan focuses on innovations supporting the commercial aviation industry's goal of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

projects.title: Boeing 777X
projects.description: The Boeing 777X is a modern, fuel-efficient twinjet airliner being developed by Boeing Commercial Airplanes. It is the latest series of the long-range, wide-body 777 family, with a longer fuselage, new engines, and folding wingtips to increase efficiency and range.

projects.title: Boeing 787 Dreamliner
projects.description: The Boeing 787 Dreamliner is a long-range, mid-size wide-body twin-engine jet airliner. It is Boeing's most fuel-efficient airliner and features composite materials that make it lighter and more cost-effective to operate.

projects.title: Boeing X-37
projects.description: The Boeing X-37 is an unmanned reusable spacecraft designed for orbital test missions. It is operated by the United States Air Force for orbital test missions and has completed several classified missions.

featuredContent.title: Boeing Research & Technology Center (Japan)
featuredContent.description: A new research center in Japan focused on innovations to support the commercial aviation industry's goal of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

images.caption: Image for Boeing Research & Technology Center (Japan)

featuredContent.title: ecoDemonstrator Program
featuredContent.description: A program that evaluates new technologies on Boeing aircraft, including sustainable components made from recycled carbon fiber and bio-based resin, with the goal of enhancing sustainability and reducing environmental impact.

featuredContent.title: More Efficient Aircraft Concepts
featuredContent.description: NASA has awarded Boeing a $425 million contract as part of its Sustainable Flight Demonstrator program. The collaboration aims to build, test, and fly a full-scale demonstrator aircraft featuring new technologies designed to reduce emissions. Boeing's concept, called 'Transonic Truss-Braced Wing' is shown here.

organizations.name: Northrop Grumman
organizations.description: Through multiple research facilities, including its Advanced Technology Lab in Maryland, Northrop Grumman develops aerospace and defense systems. Its aerospace and defense technologies are developed through various divisions and facilities. The company's Advanced Technology Lab (ATL) in Linthicum, Maryland, offers a range of microelectronics and semiconductor services, including semiconductor foundry technologies, test and assembly services, compound technology, and mixed-signal radiation capabilities. With approximately 22,000 ft² of cleanroom space, the ATL provides microelectronics test, assembly, and product engineering services for internally and externally fabricated products. Northrop Grumman's research portfolio spans space systems, cybersecurity, autonomous systems, and quantum technologies. The company is developing satellites for the Space Development Agency's Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture. It offers cyber technologies like the Cyberdefense Platform for Weapon Systems (CyPaWS) and the Cyber Warning Receiver (CyWRv). Regarding autonomous systems, Northrop Grumman is developing mission-focused capabilities like Helix and Scion.

projects.title: James Webb Space Telescope
projects.description: The James Webb Space Telescope is a revolutionary space observatory developed by NASA, with major contributions from Northrop Grumman. It is designed to study the first galaxies formed after the Big Bang and observe the formation of stars and planets. Northrop Grumman was the prime contractor and led the design and development of the telescope's optics, sunshield, and spacecraft.

images.caption: Image for James Webb Space Telescope
Image for James Webb Space Telescope

projects.title: B-2 Spirit Stealth Bomber
projects.description: The B-2 Spirit is a strategic stealth bomber developed by Northrop Grumman for the United States Air Force. It is a flying-wing design with advanced stealth technology, making it virtually undetectable to enemy radar. The B-2 has been a key component of the U.S. military's long-range strike capabilities since the late 1990s.

images.caption: Image for B-2 Spirit Stealth Bomber
Image for B-2 Spirit Stealth Bomber

projects.title: Global Hawk Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)
projects.description: The Global Hawk is a high-altitude, long-endurance unmanned aerial vehicle developed by Northrop Grumman for the U.S. Air Force. It is designed for intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance missions, providing real-time imagery and data collection capabilities. The Global Hawk has been extensively used in various military operations since its introduction in the early 2000s.

images.caption: Image for Global Hawk Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)

organizations.name: RTX
organizations.description: Connecticut-based RTX, formed through the 2020 merger of Raytheon and United Technologies, employs 185,000 people, including 60,000 engineers and scientists, across three divisions: Collins Aerospace, Pratt & Whitney, and Raytheon. The company's Technology Research Center develops materials science, propulsion systems, and quantum computing technologies, while its commercial aviation work focuses on reducing CO₂ emissions. Recent projects include hybrid-electric systems targeting 30% better fuel efficiency and the GTF Advantage engine reducing CO₂ emissions by 17%. In 2023, RTX reported $68.9 billion in sales and achieved a $196 billion backlog, split between $118 billion in commercial and $78 billion in defense contracts.

featuredContent.title: Sustainable Aviation Technologies
featuredContent.description: RTX is working on developing fuel-efficient engines and other sustainable aviation technologies to reduce CO2 emissions in the commercial aviation industry. Shown here is the Pratt & Whitney and Collins Aerospace hybrid electric demonstrator on a De Havilland Dash 8 regional aircraft backed by the governments of Canada and Quebec.

featuredContent.description: Researchers at the RTX Technology Research Center are using AI to analyze decades’ worth of research in materials science and propose new alloys from more than 600 billion possible combinations.

organizations.name: Airbus
organizations.description: Operating from Leiden, Netherlands, Airbus Defense and Space employs 250 professionals at its specialized division developing launcher structures and solar arrays for spacecraft. In 2024, the company advanced pilot automation through its Optimate demonstrator for automatic taxiing, while partnering with Toshiba to develop superconducting systems for hydrogen-powered aircraft. The division's work spans thermoplastic composites that reduce structural weight by 10% and automated ultrasonic welding techniques for cleaner assembly. Through its Acubed center in Silicon Valley and innovation hubs in China and Europe, Airbus tests rapid prototypes and new technologies. The company recently invested in LanzaJet to scale up sustainable aviation fuel production using alcohol-to-jet technology, while developing bio-based composites using atmospheric carbon capture.

projects.title: Airbus A350 XWB
projects.description: The Airbus A350 XWB (Extra Wide Body) is a long-range, wide-body jet airliner developed by Airbus. It is designed to be more fuel-efficient and environmentally friendly than previous generation aircraft. The A350 XWB features advanced aerodynamics, lightweight composite materials, and new engine technology to reduce fuel consumption and emissions.

projects.title: Airbus A320neo
projects.description: The Airbus A320neo (New Engine Option) is a re-engined and upgraded version of the popular A320 single-aisle aircraft family. It features new, more fuel-efficient engines and aerodynamic improvements to reduce fuel consumption and emissions. The A320neo has been a commercial success for Airbus, with thousands of orders from airlines around the world.

projects.title: Airbus A380
projects.description: The Airbus A380 is a double-deck, wide-body airliner, the largest passenger airliner in the world. It was a groundbreaking project for Airbus, pushing the boundaries of aircraft design and manufacturing. The A380 can accommodate up to 853 passengers in a typical three-class configuration, making it ideal for high-density routes.

featuredContent.title: Airbus Introduces Cryoprop for Next-Gen Aircraft Propulsion
featuredContent.description: Airbus UpNext has unveiled the Cryoprop, a new technological demonstrator featuring a 2 megawatt-class superconducting electric propulsion system cooled by liquid hydrogen. This project aims to accelerate the development of superconducting technologies for future hydrogen-powered aircraft.

images.caption: Airbus Launches Cryoprop for Next-Gen Aircraft Propulsion

organizations.name: General Atomics
organizations.description: Specializing in fusion energy, defense systems, and nuclear technologies, General Atomics is an innovation powerhouse. The company operates the DIII-D National Fusion Facility in San Diego, California, on behalf of the U.S. Department of Energy, which is the largest tokamak fusion research facility in the United States. In nuclear technologies, General Atomics conducts research on reactors, including high-temperature gas-cooled reactors, fast neutron reactors, and small modular reactors. The company's defense systems division develops and manufactures unmanned aircraft systems like the MQ-9 Reaper and MQ-1C Gray Eagle, as well as electromagnetic aircraft launch and recovery systems for naval carriers and directed energy weapons. General Atomics also produces electromagnetic systems, including superconducting magnets for particle accelerators and fusion reactors, linear accelerators for medical and industrial applications, and electromagnetic rail gun systems. With over 8.3 million square feet of facilities globally, including engineering laboratories and manufacturing plants, General Atomics employs approximately 12,500 people across its various divisions and subsidiaries.

projects.title: Predator Drone Program
projects.description: General Atomics is known for its development of the Predator and Reaper unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), which have been widely used by the U.S. military for reconnaissance and strike missions. The Predator drone program has been a significant project for General Atomics, revolutionizing the use of unmanned aircraft in modern warfare.

projects.title: TRIGA Research Reactors
projects.description: General Atomics has been a leading developer of TRIGA (Training, Research, Isotopes, General Atomics) research reactors, which are small nuclear reactors used for training, research, and isotope production. These reactors have been installed at universities and research facilities around the world.

projects.title: EM2 Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System
projects.description: General Atomics has developed the EM2 Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System, which uses electromagnetic forces to launch aircraft from the deck of an aircraft carrier, eliminating the need for traditional steam catapults. This technology has the potential to revolutionize naval aviation.

images.caption: Image for EM2 Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System
Image for EM2 Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System

featuredContent.title: DIII-D National Fusion Facility
featuredContent.description: The DIII-D National Fusion Facility is a tokamak fusion reactor operated by General Atomics for the U.S. Department of Energy. It is one of the largest and most advanced fusion research facilities in the world, conducting experiments to study plasma confinement and stability, and develop fusion energy as a potential future power source.

images.caption: Image for DIII-D National Fusion Facility

featuredContent.title: Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System (EMALS)
featuredContent.description: General Atomics has developed the Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System (EMALS), a cutting-edge technology that uses electromagnetic forces to launch aircraft from naval carriers. This system replaces the traditional steam catapult and offers significant advantages in terms of efficiency, reliability, and reduced maintenance requirements.

images.caption: Image for Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System (EMALS)

organizations.name: Thales
organizations.description: From its network of university-based research laboratories, Thales develops defense, aerospace, and digital security technologies across 68 countries. The French multinational, jointly owned by the state and Dassault Aviation, with each holding 26% stakes, reported €18.4 billion in 2023 sales. Thales Research & Technology invests €4 billion annually in R&D, with €1.1 billion self-funded, representing 6% of sales. The company leads Europe in AI patents for mission-critical systems, employing over 600 AI experts and hosting 100 Ph.D. students annually who integrate AI capabilities into more than 100 products. In 2024, Thales completed strategic moves, including selling its Transport division to Hitachi Rail and acquiring Cobham Aerospace Communications. The company also implemented a share buyback program, purchasing 7,469,396 shares for €966 million.

projects.title: Galileo Navigation System
projects.description: Thales is a major industrial partner in the Galileo Navigation System, Europe's global navigation satellite system. The company is responsible for developing and manufacturing key components, including atomic clocks, navigation payloads, and ground control systems. Galileo aims to provide accurate positioning and timing services for various applications, including transportation, agriculture, and emergency response.

projects.title: Scorpion Helmet-Mounted Sight and Display
projects.description: Thales has developed the Scorpion Helmet-Mounted Sight and Display, a cutting-edge system that enhances situational awareness for military pilots. It integrates advanced optics, sensors, and display technology, allowing pilots to access critical information and target data directly in their line of sight.

images.caption: Image for Scorpion Helmet-Mounted Sight and Display
Image for Scorpion Helmet-Mounted Sight and Display

projects.title: Watchkeeper Unmanned Aerial Vehicle
projects.description: Thales played a key role in the development of the Watchkeeper Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) for the British Army. This advanced UAV system is designed for intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance missions, providing real-time data and imagery to support military operations.

images.caption: Image for Watchkeeper Unmanned Aerial Vehicle
Image for Watchkeeper Unmanned Aerial Vehicle

featuredContent.title: Thales Research & Technology (TRT)
featuredContent.description: TRT is Thales' central research laboratory, leading innovation across the company in areas such as artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, big data, connectivity, autonomous systems, and quantum technology.

featuredContent.title: Autonomous Train Operation
featuredContent.description: Thales has been working on developing autonomous train operation systems, which can automatically control the speed, braking, and other functions of trains, improving safety and efficiency.

organizations.name: BAE Systems
organizations.description: From its Great Baddow research facility established in 1936, BAE Systems has grown into Britain's largest defense contractor, operating specialized labs, including a 110,000-square-foot semiconductor fabrication center in Nashua, New Hampshire. The company's FAST Labs division develops electronic warfare systems and autonomous technologies, while its AI Labs focuses on machine learning applications for defense. In 2024, BAE secured a $48 million U.S. Air Force contract to develop the Insight system, which uses predictive analytics and machine learning to process intelligence data. According to its annual report, the company increased R&D spending by 14% in 2023, with work spanning from quantum information processing to AI-enabled aircraft inspection systems.

projects.title: Eurofighter Typhoon
projects.description: The Eurofighter Typhoon is a highly advanced multi-role combat aircraft developed by a consortium of European companies, including BAE Systems. It is one of the most sophisticated and capable fighter jets in the world, featuring advanced avionics, sensors, and weapons systems. The Typhoon has been in service with several air forces since the early 2000s and continues to undergo upgrades and enhancements.

projects.title: F-35 Lightning II
projects.description: The F-35 Lightning II is a highly advanced, multi-role stealth fighter developed by Lockheed Martin in partnership with several companies, including BAE Systems. BAE Systems is responsible for the design and production of various components, including the aft fuselage, horizontal and vertical tails, and other critical systems.

projects.title: Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carriers
projects.description: The Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carriers are the largest warships ever built for the Royal Navy. BAE Systems played a significant role in the design and construction of these carriers, which are equipped with advanced aviation and combat systems.

images.caption: Image for Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carriers

featuredContent.title: AIR program
featuredContent.description: DARPA has awarded BAE Systems a $4 million Phase 1 contract for the Artificial Intelligence Reinforcements (AIR) program, which aims to advance dominant tactical autonomy for beyond visual range air combat missions.

featuredContent.title: Fight Tonight program
featuredContent.description: A $17 million contract awarded by the Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL) to develop an autonomy-based video game experience for mission planners.

featuredContent.title: Marconi Research Laboratory Legacy
featuredContent.description: BAE Systems' research legacy dates back to the 1936 Marconi Research Laboratory. The Marconi Research Laboratory, established in 1936 at Great Baddow, Essex, UK, has played a role in advances in telecommunications, electronics, and defense. Originally part of Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company, it underwent several ownership changes over the decades. In 1999, Marconi Electronic Systems (which included the research center) merged with British Aerospace to form BAE Systems

images.caption: Image for Marconi Research Laboratory Legacy

organizations.name: General Motors
organizations.description: Founded in 1908, General Motors established the world's first automotive research organization in 1920 under Charles Kettering. The GM Research Labs achieved several notable firsts, including the development of successful lacquer paint systems that dramatically reduced production time, and the creation of the first vehicle emissions control device (PCV valve). A significant milestone was the development of the 1966 Electrovair II with a 532-volt silver-zinc battery pack, demonstrating early innovation in electric vehicles. The company made computing history in 1956 when Robert L. Patrick and Owen Mock created the world's first computer operating system, GM-NAA I/O. Today, GM's R&D team focuses on three primary objectives: achieving zero crashes through safety technologies, zero emissions through electrification, and zero congestion through autonomous driving development. The company maintains strong academic partnerships, particularly with Brown University, where collaboration began in 2001 through the GM/Brown Collaborative Research Laboratory. In 2017, the company launched Super Cruise, a hands-free driver assistance system. This system incorporates driver attention features using head position and gaze tracking, while also integrating multiple sensor technologies including cameras, LiDAR, GPS, and radar for autonomous capabilities.

organizations.name: Continental
organizations.description: Focused on transport technologies and connected vehicles, Continental is an automotive supplier and technology company that does much more than make tires. Continental led the 2020 European Patent Office's patent index for transport technologies. Its Hanover Development Center employs approximately 1,000 researchers, designers, and engineers. Tires are, of course, important for the firm. It rigorously tests its tires, with new models covering 25 million kilometers annually on test rigs and tracks before production at facilities in Arvidsjaur, Jeversen, Uvalde, and Hefei, conducting over 67,000 tire tests annually. Continental's research spans autonomous driving, electrification, and software-defined vehicles. Beyond its core facilities, the Taraxagum Lab Anklam specifically researches dandelion rubber. Continental has made strides in vehicle connectivity and autonomous systems, including a partnership with Aurora for autonomous trucking systems planned for 2027 production. Recent developments include the introduction of ContiConnect Lite and Pro tire management technologies, and the UltraContact NXT tire comprising up to 65% renewable, recycled, and mass-balance-certified materials.

organizations.name: BMW
organizations.description: Located in Munich, the BMW Research and Innovation Center (FIZ) houses approximately 20,000 employees developing future mobility technologies within a 500,000+ square meter facility. The recent FIZ Nord expansion adds 100 test benches and 200 laboratories, focusing on electrification, digitalization, and sustainability. BMW also maintains a global R&D presence, with centers in China (Shanghai, Beijing, and Shenyang) and Korea. The company continues to strengthen its global R&D network through strategic investments, with China representing its largest R&D footprint outside Germany with over 3,200 engineers and designers, while the newly opened Korean facility in Incheon focuses on vehicle homologation and electrification technology validation, employing around 50 people and aiming to handle all certification testing in-house within 3-4 years.

projects.title: BMW iNEXT
projects.description: The BMW iNEXT is an upcoming all-electric flagship SUV from BMW, scheduled for release in 2022. It is designed to showcase BMW's latest innovations in autonomous driving, connectivity, and electric mobility. The iNEXT is expected to feature Level 3 autonomous driving capabilities and a range of up to 600 km on a single charge.

projects.title: BMW i3
projects.description: The BMW i3 is an all-electric compact car that was launched in 2013. It was one of the first mass-produced electric vehicles from a major automaker and featured a lightweight carbon fiber reinforced plastic body and a range of up to 200 km.

projects.title: BMW iX
projects.description: The BMW iX is an all-electric luxury SUV that was unveiled in 2021. It features a range of up to 600 km, advanced driver assistance systems, and a sleek, aerodynamic design.

featuredContent.title: BMW iNEXT Project

organizations.name: Hyundai Motors
organizations.description: Hyundai Motor Group's R&D efforts encompass a broad range of innovations including sustainable mobility, software-defined vehicles, electrification, driver assistance systems, robotics, and AI technologies. The Namyang R&D Center in Hwaseong, Gyeonggi-do, serves as a central hub connecting Hyundai's local and global research, featuring comprehensive facilities for design, driving tests, aerodynamic research, and pilot production across its 3.3 million square meter facility. Hyundai and Kia have restructured their R&D organization to accelerate development of electric and software-defined vehicles using an 'Alliance Tech Organization' model that operates with startup-like agility and flexibility, creating separate divisions for Total Vehicle Development, Vehicle SW Tech Unit, and Mobility Engineering and Tech Acceleration. Additionally, Hyundai Motor, Kia, and KAIST operate a joint research lab with approximately 30 researchers focused on developing next-generation autonomous driving sensors and LiDAR technology.

projects.title: Hyundai IONIQ 5
projects.description: The IONIQ 5 is Hyundai's first dedicated electric vehicle built on a new EV platform. It features a sleek and futuristic design, a long-range battery, and ultra-fast charging capabilities. The IONIQ 5 represents Hyundai's commitment to sustainable mobility and is a significant step towards electrifying its vehicle lineup.

projects.title: Hyundai NEXO
projects.description: The NEXO is Hyundai's second-generation hydrogen fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV). It has a longer driving range and improved performance compared to its predecessor, the Tucson FCEV. The NEXO represents Hyundai's commitment to developing alternative fuel technologies for sustainable transportation.

projects.title: Hyundai Kona Electric
projects.description: The Kona Electric is Hyundai's first long-range, fully electric compact SUV. It offers a driving range of up to 258 miles on a single charge and features a modern design and advanced technology features. The Kona Electric is part of Hyundai's efforts to expand its electric vehicle lineup and cater to the growing demand for eco-friendly transportation.

organizations.name: Tesla
organizations.description: Best known for its electric vehicles, autonomous driving technologies, and energy technologies, Tesla uses a vertically integrated R&D approach encompassing battery production, robotics, and software development. Its research facilities include the Tesla Palo Alto research center and the Kato Road battery development facility, where teams focus on electric powertrains, battery technology, autonomous driving, and sustainable energy systems, leveraging AI and machine learning. The company's innovation extends into humanoid robotics with the Tesla Bot (Optimus), which shares AI technology with their vehicles and aims for mass-market accessibility at $20,000–$30,000. Their autonomous systems have accumulated 1.6 billion miles of Full Self-Driving data, while the $500 million Dojo supercomputer cluster at Gigafactory New York processes massive amounts of computer vision data. Manufacturing innovations at its Gigafactories have led to the production of over 50 million 4680 battery cells, with daily production rates reaching 126,050 cells.

organizations.name: Honda
organizations.description: Honda R&D Co., Ltd. operates as the primary research and development subsidiary of Honda Motor Company. The Honda Research Institute Japan (HRI-JP), established in 2003, executes research initiatives with a specific focus on cooperative intelligence and human-centric AI systems. The institute's research portfolio encompasses intelligent systems development, human-machine interaction, and social communication technologies, with a capital investment of 50 million yen. Following a major restructuring in 2020, Honda transformed its organizational structure from the traditional SED framework to a more integrated model under Automobile Operations, comprising specialized units including the Business Supervisory Unit, Production Supervisory Unit, Supply Chain Management Unit, Sales Supervisory Unit, and Monzoukuri Center. The research activities span multiple global facilities, with Honda Research Institutes operating in Japan (HRI-JP), USA (HRI-USA), and Europe (HRI-Europe), alongside R&D centers in Thailand, India, and Indonesia.

organizations.name: Baidu
organizations.description: Baidu has established itself as a leader in AI, autonomous driving, and cloud computing. Its ERNIE Bot has gained over 200 million users since launching in March 2023, with the API handling 200 million daily queries. Baidu Research operates facilities in Sunnyvale, California, and Beijing, focusing on human-computer interaction using natural language processing, robotics, and autonomous systems. Its Robotics and Autonomous Driving Lab (RAL) develops technologies, with the Apollo Go robotaxi service completing 839,000 rides in Q4 2023 across 3,000 square kilometers in Wuhan. Baidu's work encompasses large language models like ERNIE 4.0, cross-modal AI, AI chips, and quantum computing. The company has recently developed lightweight AI models (ERNIE Speed, ERNIE Lite, and ERNIE Tiny) and the Apollo VTA vision foundation model, trained on over 100 million kilometers of urban driving data. The Apollo Go service charges competitive rates starting at 4 yuan (55 cents) and plans to deploy 1,000 6th generation robotaxis in Wuhan by 2024, with the robotaxi division expected to achieve profitability by 2025.

organizations.description: With Q2 2024 revenue reaching $84.7 billion, Mountain View-based Alphabet oversees Google and several former Google subsidiaries. The company invested $45.4 billion in R&D during 2023, focusing on artificial intelligence and emerging technologies ranging from autonomous vehicles to protein structure prediction. Its subsidiaries include Verily and X Lab, which work on healthcare and internet accessibility, while its consolidated AI teams operate under Google DeepMind. Its AI research time is one of the most elite in the world.

projects.title: Waymo
projects.description: Originating as Google's Self-Driving Car Project in 2009 and later spun off as a separate company under Alphabet Inc, Waymo develops autonomous driving technologies. Tapping Google's extensive engineering expertise and computing resources, Waymo has made strides in self-driving technology. The company conducts extensive real-world testing in multiple cities and uses private test tracks and advanced simulation environments to develop and validate its autonomous driving systems. As of 2024, Waymo's vehicles have collectively driven more than 20 million miles and conducted over 2 million trips.

projects.title: Google Brain

organizations.name: Waymo LLC
organizations.description: Waymo began as Google's Self-Driving Car Project in 2009 and was spun off as a separate company under Alphabet Inc. (Google's parent company) in 2016. The company is a leader in the development of autonomous driving technology, leveraging Google's extensive engineering expertise and vast computing resources. Waymo has made strides in self-driving technology, having driven over 20 billion miles in simulation and 20 million miles on public roads. The company conducts extensive real-world testing across multiple cities, including Phoenix, San Francisco, and Los Angeles, while also utilizing private test tracks and simulation environments like 'Simulation City' to develop and validate its autonomous driving systems. Under the leadership of co-CEO Tekedra Mawakana, Waymo has achieved significant milestones, including over 100,000 paid autonomous trips per week, and continues to expand its services with plans to launch in Austin.

projects.title: Waymo Driver
projects.description: Waymo Driver is Waymo's self-driving technology that powers their autonomous ride-hailing service and trucking operations. It uses advanced sensors, software, and AI to navigate roads safely without human intervention. Waymo has been testing and refining this technology for over a decade, making it one of the most advanced self-driving systems in the world.

projects.title: Waymo One
projects.description: Waymo One is Waymo's commercial autonomous ride-hailing service, launched in 2020 in parts of Phoenix, Arizona. It allows members of the public to hail self-driving cars from Waymo's fleet for transportation around the service area.

projects.title: Waymo Via
projects.description: Waymo Via is Waymo's autonomous trucking and logistics solution. It aims to deploy self-driving trucks for long-haul and freight transportation, with the goal of improving efficiency, safety, and sustainability in the logistics industry.

featuredContent.title: Waymo announces strategic shift to focus on ride-hailing services
featuredContent.description: Waymo, the autonomous driving technology company, announced a strategic shift to focus primarily on its ride-hailing service, Waymo One, in 2023. The company cites significant momentum and commercial opportunities in this sector as the reason for their decision.

featuredContent.title: Waymo Via
featuredContent.description: Waymo Via is Waymo's autonomous trucking and logistics solution, aimed at improving the efficiency and safety of freight transportation. In June 2022, Waymo Via and Uber Freight announced a long-term strategic partnership to deploy autonomous trucks at scale on the Uber Freight network.

organizations.name: Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance R&D
organizations.description: The Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance, formed in 1999, invests €23 billion in electrification over the next five years. The Alliance operates manufacturing plants across major markets including Europe, Japan, US, and China, producing essential EV components and vehicles. Its 'Leader-Follower' approach optimizes resource sharing with Nissan autonomous driving development, Renault spearheading connected-car technologies, and Mitsubishi focusing on plug-in hybrid technology. Innovation hubs in Tel Aviv, Shanghai, and Silicon Valley drive progress in autonomous driving sensors, cybersecurity, and big data analytics. The Alliance strategically divides regional responsibilities, with Renault overseeing Europe, Russia, and South America; Nissan managing China, North America, and Japan; and Mitsubishi focusing on ASEAN and Oceania.

organizations.name: Toyota Central Research and Development Laboratories
organizations.description: Employing 1,000 researchers in Nagakute, Aichi, Toyota Central Research and Development Laboratories (Toyota CRDL) has conducted fundamental research since 1960. The facility integrates with Toyota's global R&D network, investigating artificial intelligence, materials science, environmental technology, and mobility. Current projects include solid-state battery development and energy storage research. The lab's materials research produced cage-shaped porous silicon for high-capacity lithium-ion batteries, while other teams work on energy-efficient manufacturing processes and carbon reduction methods. The laboratory applies Toyota's 'Kaizen' philosophy of continuous improvement to its research methodology.

projects.title: Toyota Mirai Fuel Cell Vehicle
projects.description: The Toyota Mirai is a hydrogen fuel cell electric vehicle developed by Toyota. It is one of the first mass-produced fuel cell vehicles and represents Toyota's efforts in developing sustainable mobility technologies. The Mirai generates electricity from hydrogen and oxygen, with water vapor as the only emission.

images.caption: Image for Toyota Mirai Fuel Cell Vehicle
Image for Toyota Mirai Fuel Cell Vehicle

projects.title: Toyota Prius Hybrid
projects.description: The Toyota Prius is a pioneering hybrid electric vehicle that combines a gasoline engine with an electric motor. It was one of the first mass-produced hybrid vehicles and helped popularize hybrid technology, paving the way for more fuel-efficient and environmentally friendly vehicles.

projects.title: Toyota Safety Sense
projects.description: Toyota Safety Sense is a suite of advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS) that includes features like pre-collision braking, lane departure alert, and adaptive cruise control. It represents Toyota's efforts in developing safer and more intelligent vehicles through the integration of advanced sensors and software.

featuredContent.title: Inside the Toyota Central R&D Labs
featuredContent.description: Established in 1960, this research institute in Nagakute, Aichi Prefecture, Japan, drives advances in automotive technology, electronics, materials science, and environmental technologies. With a workforce of 926 talented researchers and engineers, TCRDL collaborates closely with Toyota Group companies and global research partners to shape the future of mobility. From fuel cell materials to soft materials with applications in regenerative medicine and automotive components, the lab has a diverse focus

featuredContent.title: Autonomous Driving Research

organizations.name: Ford Motor Company
organizations.description: The Research and Advanced Engineering division of Ford operates through several strategic facilities, including the $75 million Ford Robotics Building at the University of Michigan where 100 researchers and engineers develop robotics and mobility technologies. The division's work spans autonomous vehicle testing at the Mcity Test Facility, where Ford pioneered automaker testing, development of intelligent vehicle connectivity systems that maintain cloud communication in challenging network conditions, and implementation of AI-powered manufacturing robotics, including dual-arm features. Through FordLabs, the company conducts rapid experimentation and research validation using human-centered, data-driven approaches, while its global network of electrified vehicle research facilities operates on a 'hub and spoke' model that supports real-time virtual battery testing across international teams.

projects.title: Ford Mustang Mach-E
projects.description: The Ford Mustang Mach-E is Ford's first all-electric SUV and one of the company's most significant electric vehicle initiatives. Launched in 2020, the Mach-E aims to bring the iconic Mustang nameplate into the electric era, offering a range of up to 300 miles and advanced technology features.

projects.title: Ford F-150 Lightning
projects.description: The Ford F-150 Lightning is Ford's first all-electric pickup truck, set to launch in 2022. It aims to bring the iconic F-150 nameplate into the electric vehicle era, offering impressive towing and hauling capabilities while producing zero emissions.

projects.title: Ford Model T
projects.description: The Ford Model T, introduced in 1908, was one of the most influential and groundbreaking projects in automotive history. It was the first affordable automobile for the masses, revolutionizing transportation and manufacturing with its assembly line production.

organizations.name: Intel
organizations.description: Santa Clara-based Intel, reporting $12.8 billion in Q2 2024 revenue, leads semiconductor innovation through its research and manufacturing capabilities. Intel Labs advances foundational technologies spanning cloud computing, data centers, and artificial intelligence, while the company's manufacturing arm develops next-generation process nodes. The company achieved key milestones on Intel 18A with its 1.0 Process Design Kit release and successful power-on of first client and server products - Panther Lake and Clearwater Forest. Expected to begin production in 2025, Intel 18A will feature RibbonFET transistor design and PowerVia backside power delivery technology, positioning Intel to regain process leadership. The company has secured strategic partnerships, including a multi-year, multi-billion-dollar collaboration with AWS to produce custom chips using both Intel 18A and Intel 3 process nodes.

projects.title: Intel Loihi Neuromorphic Chip
projects.description: Intel Loihi is a self-learning neuromorphic chip designed to mimic the human brain's neural pathways. It is capable of on-chip learning and can adapt to new inputs and environments, making it suitable for applications like robotics, cybersecurity, and autonomous systems. Loihi represents a significant step towards more efficient and intelligent computing architectures.

images.caption: Image for Intel Loihi Neuromorphic Chip
Image for Intel Loihi Neuromorphic Chip

projects.title: Intel Optane Memory
projects.description: Intel Optane Memory is a revolutionary non-volatile memory technology that combines the attributes of memory and storage. It offers high-performance, low-latency, and high-endurance, bridging the gap between traditional DRAM and storage devices. Optane Memory accelerates system responsiveness and enables new data-centric use cases.

projects.title: Intel Xeon Scalable Processors
projects.description: The Intel Xeon Scalable Processors are a family of high-performance server and workstation CPUs designed for demanding workloads. They feature advanced technologies like Intel Mesh Architecture, Intel Optane DC Persistent Memory, and built-in AI acceleration, enabling high scalability, efficiency, and performance for data centers and enterprise applications.

images.caption: Image for Intel Xeon Scalable Processors
Image for Intel Xeon Scalable Processors

featuredContent.title: Intel Labs
featuredContent.description: Intel Labs is Intel's research organization focused on developing technologies related to cloud computing, data center technology, the Internet of Things, artificial intelligence, and advanced computing.

featuredContent.title: Intel Neuromorphic Research
featuredContent.description: Intel has been conducting research on neuromorphic computing, which aims to develop computer architectures inspired by the human brain's structure and function. This project explores new computing paradigms beyond traditional von Neumann architectures.

featuredContent.title: Intel Quantum Computing Research
featuredContent.description: Intel has been investing in quantum computing research, exploring the potential of quantum computing for solving complex problems more efficiently than classical computers. This includes research on quantum hardware, software, and algorithms.

images.caption: Image for Intel Quantum Computing Research

organizations.name: Robert Bosch
organizations.description: The global technology and services company Bosch conducts R&D through its Bosch Research arm, which comprises roughly 1,800 experts worldwide. Bosch's research focuses on mobility, artificial intelligence, sustainable technologies, automation, digitalization, electrification, climate action, and healthcare. The company maintains research centers globally and collaborates with universities and industry partners. The company has established significant academic partnerships with prestigious institutions including Carnegie Mellon, and the Universities of Freiburg, Tübingen, and Amsterdam. Bosch researchers contribute to 25% of the company's annual patent applications. The company has made significant financial commitments, including €3.7 million for AI research at the University of Freiburg, €2.5 billion in hydrogen technologies development (2021–2026), and $1.5 billion for a semiconductor wafer fab in Roseville, California. The Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence (BCAI) serves as their center of excellence, coordinating AI initiatives across the organization.

projects.title: Bosch Mobility Cloud
projects.description: The Bosch Mobility Cloud is a cloud-based platform that provides connected mobility services for vehicles, including over-the-air software updates, predictive diagnostics, and fleet management technologies. It aims to enhance the driving experience, improve vehicle efficiency, and enable new business models for automakers and mobility service providers.

projects.title: Bosch Automotive Cloud Suite
projects.description: The Bosch Automotive Cloud Suite is a comprehensive set of cloud-based technologies for the automotive industry, enabling connected vehicle services, data management, and advanced analytics. It helps automakers and suppliers develop and deploy connected car features, optimize vehicle performance, and gain insights from vehicle data.

projects.title: Bosch IoT Suite
projects.description: The Bosch IoT Suite is a platform for the Internet of Things (IoT), providing a range of services and tools for connecting and managing IoT devices, collecting and analyzing data, and developing IoT applications across various industries, including manufacturing, energy, and smart cities.

featuredContent.title: Bosch Center for Artificial Intelligence
featuredContent.description: A major research group focused on developing AI technologies for applications in mobility, manufacturing, and consumer products. Key areas include machine learning, computer vision, and robotics.

featuredContent.title: Automated Valet Parking
featuredContent.description: A pioneering project that developed an automated valet parking system using AI, sensors, and vehicle control systems. It enables vehicles to navigate parking facilities and park themselves without a driver.

organizations.name: IBM
organizations.description: Established in 1945, IBM Research is one of the world's largest industrial research organizations, with 12 laboratories globally. It has published over 110,000 research papers and focuses on artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and hybrid cloud technologies. IBM Research emphasizes responsible AI development, open research, and collaboration. Its researchers have received six Nobel Prizes and six Turing Awards. The organization has been instrumental in developing technologies like the scanning tunneling microscope and high-temperature superconductivity. Additionally, IBM Research has had more than 150,000 patents awarded to date.

projects.title: IBM Watson
projects.description: IBM Watson is a question-answering computer system capable of answering questions posed in natural language. It was developed by IBM and first gained fame after defeating human champions on the TV quiz show Jeopardy! in 2011. Watson represents a major advancement in artificial intelligence and natural language processing.

projects.title: IBM Deep Blue
projects.description: Deep Blue was a chess-playing computer developed by IBM. It was the first computer system to defeat a reigning world chess champion, Garry Kasparov, in a match under standard chess tournament rules. Deep Blue's victory in 1997 was a landmark achievement in the field of artificial intelligence.

projects.title: IBM Roadrunner
projects.description: Roadrunner was a supercomputer built by IBM for the Los Alamos National Laboratory. It was the first system to break the petaflop barrier, achieving a peak performance of 1.105 petaflops. Roadrunner held the title of the world's fastest supercomputer from 2008 to 2009.

featuredContent.title: MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab
featuredContent.description: The MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab is a research group focused on advancing artificial intelligence technologies, including machine learning, natural language processing, and computer vision. Based in Kendall Square, MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab manages a research portfolio of more than 80 projects.

featuredContent.title: IBM Research – Brazil
featuredContent.description: Established in 2010 with locations in São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, IBM Research Brazil focuses on advancing artificial intelligence, hybrid cloud, and quantum computing. The lab's researchers work on key challenges including climate science, conversational AI, responsible technology development, and accelerated materials discovery.

featuredContent.title: IBM Quantum Experience
featuredContent.description: The IBM Quantum Experience is a pioneering project that provides access to IBM's quantum computing systems over the cloud. It allows researchers, scientists, and developers to experiment with quantum algorithms and explore the potential of quantum computing.

featuredContent.title: IBM Watson
featuredContent.description: IBM Watson is a groundbreaking project that developed a question-answering system capable of understanding natural language and providing accurate responses. It has been applied in various domains, including healthcare, finance, and customer service.

organizations.name: Microsoft
organizations.description: Redmond-based Microsoft Research employs more than 1,000 scientists, engineers and mathematicians across seven global labs. Founded in 1991 by Richard Rashid, Bill Gates and Nathan Myhrvold, MSR's largest facility in Redmond hosts 350 researchers focused on AI, systems and human-computer interaction. Its network includes labs in Cambridge, UK (est. 1997), Beijing and Shanghai (est. 1998 with 600 combined researchers and visiting scientists), Bengaluru, and two U.S. locations - Cambridge, Massachusetts (est. 2008) and New York City (est. 2012). With annual investments between $10-14 billion since 2010, MSR's work spans foundational computer science to applied research, contributing key technologies to products like HoloLens and Kinect while advancing fields from quantum computing to climate science.

organizations.name: OpenAI
organizations.description: Founded in 2015, OpenAI is an AI research laboratory that operates through both non-profit and for-profit structures, focused on ensuring artificial general intelligence (AGI) benefits humanity. It has made significant breakthroughs in machine learning, particularly in natural language processing, generative AI, and reasoning capabilities. OpenAI developed AI models including GPT-4, DALL·E, Codex, and Sora for text-to-video generation, as well as the o1 series focused on reasoning. The organization combines research with AI safety and ethics, working across text, image, audio, and video generation technologies. Recent work emphasizes AI reasoning and safety in scientific settings, demonstrated through collaborations with institutions like Los Alamos National Laboratory and NIST's AI Safety Institute. The company has attracted substantial investment, notably through a multibillion-dollar partnership with Microsoft, which serves as their exclusive cloud provider. While OpenAI initially emphasized open science, they have adjusted their approach, acknowledging that safety and security concerns may limit traditional publishing. Despite some controversy regarding its shift from purely non-profit status, OpenAI maintains a charter focused on long-term safety, broadly distributed benefits, and cooperative orientation in AI development, though its direction has been questioned by former associates including Elon Musk.

organizations.name: Samsung Group
organizations.description: Employing more than 10,000 researchers across global R&D centers, Samsung Research leads development for Consumer Electronics and IT & Mobile Communications divisions. Samsung's R&D activities are under the leadership of Samsung Research, the hub for its SET (End-products) Business, and the Samsung Advanced Institute of Technology (SAIT). SAIT functions as the Chief Technology Office (CTO) for the Samsung group. Samsung Research America, headquartered in Mountain View, collaborates with partners in Silicon Valley and across the U.S. Samsung's R&D encompasses next-generation communications, artificial intelligence, digital media, mobile platforms, and semiconductor technologies. The company maintains 14 overseas R&D centers in 12 countries and operates seven global AI centers. Samsung's commitment to innovation has resulted in a significant patent portfolio, including 48,798 active patent families, 22,076 expired patent families, and 19,412 pending patent families.

organizations.name: Amazon
organizations.description: Amazon's AI research and development integrates both custom hardware and sophisticated software to drive innovation and efficiency. On the hardware front, AWS Trainium is designed to train large-scale models with over 100 billion parameters, offering up to 50% cost savings and a 29% reduction in energy use. The second-generation Trainium2 enhances these benefits by providing four times faster training and twice the energy efficiency of its predecessor. For inference tasks, AWS Inferentia2 significantly outperforms the first generation, delivering four times higher throughput, ten times lower latency, and 16.4 times greater memory bandwidth with 32 GB of high-bandwidth memory per chip, resulting in up to 40% better price performance compared to comparable instances. Amazon SageMaker serves as the platform for ML projects. Additionally, Amazon offers features including toxicity detection and content moderation. Research initiatives include a $25 million commitment over ten years to partnerships with the University of Washington and the University of Tsukuba, focusing on generative AI, responsible AI governance, distributed training, and machine learning compiler optimizations. Amazon Lab126 collaborates with institutions like the University of Maryland. In addition, Amazon collaborates with industry leaders like NVIDIA, Intel, and AMD, while also developing custom silicon systems to optimize performance, cost, and energy efficiency for diverse AI workloads.

organizations.name: Meta Platforms, Inc.
organizations.description: Meta's R&D is conducted through Meta AI Research and Reality Labs, which bring together experts to advance artificial intelligence, virtual and augmented reality, and social connection technologies. The company invests heavily in fundamental AI research, including large language models, computer vision, and speech recognition, with over 50 research papers published annually. A significant component of Meta's AI ecosystem is PyTorch, an open-source deep learning framework initially developed by Meta's AI Research lab (FAIR). PyTorch has become one of the most widely used frameworks in both academia and industry owing to its flexibility and ease of use. Its Reality Labs division has made significant technical breakthroughs in haptic feedback and eye-tracking technology for VR headsets. This research arm operates at a substantial loss, recording billions in operating losses in recent years.

organizations.name: Apple
organizations.description: Apple's R&D in AI and related fields emphasizes user privacy, on-device processing, and seamless integration of AI technologies. Its machine learning teams research computer vision, natural language processing, speech recognition, and augmented reality. Apple operates numerous R&D centers globally, including the Apple Multimedia Lab, founded in 1987. The company has significantly increased its AI research budget, investing over $22 billion in R&D during 2023 alone. Apple Developer Centers host developer sessions, labs, and workshops. Apple integrates AI technologies into products like Siri, Face ID, and Apple Maps. The company recently expanded its neural engine capabilities in the latest M3 chips, demonstrating its commitment to advancing on-device AI processing power.

organizations.name: Qualcomm
organizations.description: Qualcomm Research, Qualcomm's R&D arm, focuses on wireless technology. With over $70 billion invested in R&D since its inception, Qualcomm has pioneered wireless innovations for decades. Its research covers 5G and 6G, mobile processors, IoT, autonomous vehicles, and extended reality (XR). R&D investment accounts for more than 20% of Qualcomm's annual revenue since 2006. The company maintains a global network of research facilities across North America, Europe, and Asia to drive innovation in emerging technologies. Qualcomm collaborates with academic institutions, including the Qualcomm Institute at UC San Diego. The company's most recent annual R&D expenditure was $8.818 billion for fiscal year 2023, with a quarterly R&D expense of $2.259 billion as of June 2024. Qualcomm's strong commitment to innovation is reflected in its portfolio of more than 140,000 patents and patent applications, focusing on commercializing foundational technologies for the wireless industry through its various business segments.

organizations.name: Huawei Technologies
organizations.description: Huawei Technologies, a telecommunications equipment and consumer electronics company, focuses on AI research and development. It developed the Pangu large language models, the HarmonyOS NEXT AI-native operating system, and AI hardware like the Atlas 900 AI supercomputing cluster. Huawei's AI research includes network intelligence, embodied AI, and optoelectronics. The company has invested over CNY 1.11 trillion in R&D in the past decade. Its research centers, including the Lianqiu Lake R&D Center and the Beijing Research Center, house thousands of scientists and engineers. The company's commitment to innovation is further demonstrated by its portfolio of over 140,000 active patents worldwide. The Inspiration Lab (iLab) focuses on optical technology innovation, and its global research centers contribute to progress in 5G/6G, IoT, and smart city technologies.

organizations.name: NVIDIA
organizations.description: NVIDIA Research advances AI across an array of disciplines, focusing on GPU architectures, deep learning, AI hardware acceleration, autonomous systems, and graphics rendering. Its contributions span high-performance computing, computer vision, robotics, and applied perception. NVIDIA collaborates with academic institutions and operates a global network of research facilities. Its research areas include 3D deep learning, algorithms and numerical methods, and AI and machine learning. NVIDIA Research has presented over 50 papers at CVPR 2024, with two papers selected as Best Paper Award finalists — one on diffusion model training dynamics and another on high-definition maps for autonomous vehicles. The research group conducts work across multiple domains including computer vision, machine learning, robotics, and graphics rendering, with recent breakthroughs in areas like visual generative AI models, 3D scene editing, and autonomous vehicle perception.

organizations.name: Vector Institute
organizations.description: The Vector Institute bridges academic AI research and industry applications. It attracts AI and machine learning researchers and focuses on machine learning, deep learning, and their applications in health, science, and responsible AI development. The institute fosters collaboration among researchers, startups, enterprises, and health partners, promoting responsible AI practices. Through notable partnerships with universities and companies, the Vector Institute helps drive innovation and economic growth in Canada's AI ecosystem. The institute has recently launched a Global AI Alliance for Climate Action initiative to connect its AI research community with international climate action groups to develop sustainable technologies for environmental challenges. Vector works extensively in healthcare, partnering with over 30 hospitals and 30 health organizations to implement AI technologies for improved patient care and system efficiency. The institute's research community comprises over 860 members who are advancing breakthroughs across various notable priorities including machine learning, deep learning, AI for science, trustworthy AI, AI for health, and foundation models.

organizations.name: Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence
organizations.description: The Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence (AI2), founded in 2013 by Paul G. Allen, is a nonprofit research institute advancing AI for the benefit of humanity. Led by CEO Ali Farhadi, AI2 conducts research and engineering across various AI domains using an open science approach. Its research spans natural language processing, computer vision, machine learning, and reasoning, with a recent focus on large language models, environmental applications of AI, and AI ethics. AI2 has created benchmarks, datasets, and open-source tools for the AI community.

organizations.name: Tencent
organizations.description: Tencent AI Lab, established in April 2016, focuses on both fundamental AI research and practical applications. Its core research areas include computer vision, speech recognition technology, natural language processing (NLP), and machine learning. The lab operates at a significant scale with over 50 world-class AI scientists and more than 200 engineers dedicated to application development, including a research facility in Seattle opened in 2017. The lab successfully integrates its technologies into numerous Tencent products, including WeChat, QQ, Tencent News, and QQ Music, with implementations across over 100 Tencent products and services. Notable progress includes the launch of Hunyuan, a large language model for enterprise use in 2023. Its research extends into various fields including life sciences, healthcare, and other industry applications. The lab maintains active collaborations with academic institutions and continues to make significant contributions to the global AI research community through its fundamental research and practical applications.
