organizations.name: NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research
organizations.description: The National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) advances understanding of Earth's atmosphere, climate, and related systems. Managed by UCAR and sponsored by the NSF, NCAR conducts research across eight specialized laboratories and programs, covering topics ranging from the Sun's influence on Earth's atmosphere to climate modeling. NCAR uses facilities like the Mesa Laboratory in Boulder, Colorado, and the NCAR-Wyoming Supercomputing Center, home to the \"Derecho\" supercomputer. NCAR provides researchers with access to monitoring systems, supercomputing resources, and community weather and climate models.

organizations.name: National Renewable Energy Laboratory
organizations.description: The National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), established in 1977 as the Solar Energy Research Institute, is the U.S. Department of Energy's primary laboratory for renewable energy and energy efficiency research and development. As a government-owned, contractor-operated facility managed by the Alliance for Sustainable Energy, LLC, NREL employs over 3,600 staff members and operates with a business volume of $783.5 million. The laboratory conducts research across renewable power technologies, energy efficiency innovations, sustainable transportation, and energy systems integration. As the only federal laboratory dedicated exclusively to renewable energy and energy efficiency, NREL focuses on both fundamental scientific research and practical technology development, working to transform energy challenges through tech.

organizations.name: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory
organizations.description: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (Berkeley Lab, LBNL) stands as a powerhouse of scientific innovation, built on a foundation established in 1931 with the core belief that major scientific challenges are best tackled through teamwork. The lab's excellence is demonstrated by its 14 Nobel Prizes and its consistent development of technologies across multiple disciplines. The lab's spirit is evident in its diverse portfolio of technologies. In 2022 alone, Berkeley Lab received seven R&D 100 Awards for innovations ranging from disease diagnosis to green hydrogen generation and battery technology. The following year, it earned four more R&D 100 Awards for technologies improving research tools, generating green hydrogen, and advancing materials discovery. Berkeley Lab's innovation model emphasizes strategic partnerships and collaboration. Through its Strategic Partnerships Office, the lab actively connects with researchers in both private and public sectors, regardless of organization size, to address critical energy and environmental challenges. This collaborative approach has led to numerous successful commercialization stories, from energy-saving technologies to medical innovations. The lab maintains facilities and is constantly upgrading its infrastructure to support future scientific discoveries. Major projects include the Advanced Light Source upgrade (ALS-U), the ESnet6 network for handling massive data flows, and the NERSC-10 supercomputer project scheduled for 2026. These investments ensure Berkeley Lab remains at the forefront of scientific innovation.

featuredContent.description: The Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) is an accelerator-based neutron source facility that provides the most intense pulsed neutron beams in the world for scientific research and industrial development. It is used for neutron scattering studies of materials, including superconductors, polymers, metals, and biological samples.

featuredContent.title: Summit Supercomputer
featuredContent.description: Summit is a supercomputer developed by IBM for use at ORNL. As of 2018, it was the world's most powerful and smartest scientific supercomputer, capable of performing 200 quadrillion calculations per second. It is used for advanced scientific computing and artificial intelligence applications.

organizations.name: Argonne National Laboratory
organizations.description: Argonne National Laboratory is a multidisciplinary science and engineering research center, addressing crucial challenges in clean energy, environment, technology, and national security. Founded in 1946 as the first national laboratory in the United States, Argonne has a rich history of scientific discoveries and technological innovations. The lab is known for its multidisciplinary approach, specialized facilities, focus on impactful research, and strong emphasis on entrepreneurship and technology transfer.

featuredContent.title: Advanced Photon Source (APS)
featuredContent.description: The APS is one of the most powerful and technologically advanced synchrotron X-ray light source facilities in the world. It enables researchers to study the structure and behavior of materials at the atomic and molecular levels, leading to breakthroughs in fields like materials science, chemistry, and biology.

featuredContent.title: Argonne Leadership Computing Facility (ALCF)
featuredContent.description: The ALCF provides world-class computing resources and expertise to enable breakthroughs in science and engineering. It operates some of the most powerful supercomputers in the world, including the Aurora exascale system, which will be one of the first exascale systems in the United States.

images.caption: Image for Argonne Leadership Computing Facility (ALCF)
images.credit: Image courtesy of Argonne National Laboratory

featuredContent.title: Argonne Tandem Linac Accelerator System (ATLAS)
featuredContent.description: ATLAS is a national user facility for nuclear structure research, providing high-quality beams of accelerated ions for studies of nuclear properties and nuclear astrophysics. It has played a crucial role in advancing our understanding of the atomic nucleus and the origins of the chemical elements.

organizations.name: Sandia National Laboratories
organizations.description: Sandia National Laboratories, a US Department of Energy research facility, solves national security challenges through science and engineering. Focusing on systems engineering, Sandia's multidisciplinary approach addresses nuclear deterrence, global security, energy technologies, and scientific research. Its work encompasses computational biology, physics, materials science, alternative energy, psychology, and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS).

organizations.name: Siemens
organizations.description: Siemens AG, a German multinational conglomerate, focuses on industrial innovation and technological advancement. With Europe's largest private power engineering research lab (established in Erlangen in 1965), Siemens invests in R&D addressing global challenges in energy transition, sustainability, and digital transformation. Its research activities span power engineering, industrial AI, and manufacturing technologies. Siemens operates numerous research centers, testing laboratories, and specialized facilities, including the Siemens AI Lab, which explores industrial AI applications.

organizations.name: Honeywell
organizations.description: From its Charlotte, North Carolina headquarters, Honeywell operates four strategic segments: Aerospace Technologies, Industrial Automation, Building Automation, and Energy and Sustainability Solutions. The company has strategically aligned its portfolio around three major global trends: automation, the future of aviation, and energy transition. While ESS represents 16.75% of total revenue, Honeywell's energy focus extends across all segments, with Industrial Automation providing process technologies for energy-intensive industries, Building Automation delivering energy management systems that serve over 10 million buildings worldwide, and Aerospace developing sustainable aviation fuels. The company allocates 60% of R&D spending to ESG systems and its impressive track record: since 2004, Honeywell has reduced its greenhouse gas intensity by 90% and improved energy efficiency by approximately 70%. The company projects that its technologies will help mitigate 2 billion metric tons of CO<sub>2</sub> between 2023 and 2030. Its Solstice products have already helped avoid the potential release of more than 250 million metric tons of carbon dioxide.

organizations.name: Novo Nordisk
organizations.description: Novo Nordisk, a global healthcare company founded in 1923 and headquartered in Denmark, has emerged as a biopharma leader through its development of GLP-1 therapies for obesity and diabetes. The company focuses its R&D primarily on cardiometabolic diseases, rare diseases, and blood disorders. Novo Nordisk maintains research centers in Denmark, the United States, China, the United Kingdom, and India, with facilities dedicated to early drug discovery, development, and clinical trial medicine formulation. While maintaining its core focus on metabolic diseases, the company is strategically expanding into new therapeutic areas through initiatives like its Bio Innovation Hub in Cambridge, Massachusetts, which facilitates collaborations with biotech companies and academic institutions.

organizations.name: Eli Lilly
organizations.description: Eli Lilly and Company, founded in 1876, is a rapidly growing pharmaceutical company headquartered in Indianapolis. With a 2023 R&D investment of $9.31 billion (representing 27.3% of revenue), Lilly focuses on diabetes care, oncology, immunology, and neurodegenerative diseases. The company aims to launch 20 new medicines between 2014 and 2023 and is developing genetic medicines, RNA therapeutics, and gene therapies. Its R&D network includes Lilly Gateway Labs in South San Francisco and a $700 million genetic medicine research institute in Boston's Fort Point neighborhood. With more than 42,000 employees worldwide, including 10,000 in R&D, Lilly markets its products in roughly 110 countries and has emerged as a leader in obesity treatments alongside Novo Nordisk.

organizations.name: Roche
organizations.description: Roche, a global healthcare company, invested CHF 13.2 billion in R&D in 2023. Its Basel research center houses over 1,800 scientists, clinicians, engineers, and technicians from nearly 60 countries, and its Zurich facility employs about 200 research scientists. Roche's R&D spans 17 countries across four continents, focusing on oncology, neuroscience, rare diseases, cardiovascular and metabolic diseases, immunology, infectious diseases, and ophthalmology. The company integrates diagnostics and pharmaceuticals in its business model. Roche leads Swiss companies in patent applications, with 754 applications filed to the European Patent Office in 2023.

organizations.name: Johnson & Johnson
organizations.description: Johnson & Johnson, founded in 1886, has evolved into a global healthcare leader focused on medicine and medical technology following its 2023 separation from its consumer healthcare business (now Kenvue). The company's R&D investments reached $15,805 million in 2023, representing a 7% increase from the previous year, supporting research across immunology, oncology, neuroscience, cardiovascular medicine, and infectious diseases. The company maintains a robust innovation ecosystem through various channels. Its JLABS program operates 13 life science incubators globally, including locations in the San Francisco Bay Area, Boston, Shanghai, and Toronto. The company announced a pact with NVIDIA in March 2024 to integrate AI into surgical procedures and medical technology development.

organizations.name: Medtronic
organizations.description: Medtronic, a global healthcare technology company specializing in medical devices and therapies, invested $2.7 billion in R&D and holds over 46,000 active patent matters in 2023. Its technologies address over 70 health conditions, integrating AI, data analytics, and robotics into healthcare. Medtronic's innovation strategy includes an AI Center of Excellence, an Innovation Hub, and key partnerships. Medtronic LABS' SPICE, an open-source digital platform, uses machine learning to improve healthcare delivery in underserved communities, having screened 500,000 patients and enrolled 230,000 patients globally.

organizations.name: MSD
organizations.description: Merck & Co., known as MSD outside the U.S., is a multinational pharmaceutical company with over 130 years of history. The company made a signicant R&D investment of $30.5 billion in 2023, representing about 50.8% of its total revenue, but that figure was inflated as a result of its $10.8 billion cash acquisition of Prometheus Biosciences. Its research network includes hubs in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, and California. MSD uses AI, machine learning, and data science to accelerate drug discovery and development, focusing on oncology, vaccines, infectious diseases, immunology, and neuroscience. The Merck Digital Sciences Studio and IDEA Studios support early-stage biomedical startups.

featuredContent.title: Merck Research Laboratories
featuredContent.description: Merck Research Laboratories is MSD's central R&D organization, with major sites in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, and California. It focuses on drug discovery and development across various therapeutic areas, including oncology, vaccines, infectious diseases, immunology, and neuroscience.

featuredContent.title: KEYTRUDA® (pembrolizumab)
featuredContent.description: KEYTRUDA® is MSD's leading anti-PD-1 therapy, approved for the treatment of various types of cancer, including melanoma, lung cancer, and head and neck cancer. It has been a significant contributor to MSD's oncology portfolio and a key focus of the company's research efforts.

organizations.name: Intuitive Surgical
organizations.description: Intuitive Surgical, headquartered in Sunnyvale, California, develops robotic-assisted surgery technologies, including the da Vinci Surgical System and Ion endoluminal system. The company has 13,676 employees as of December 31, 2023, and invested $998.8 million in R&D during 2023. Its research focuses on advancing robotic-assisted surgery using AI, machine learning, and data-driven insights, with areas including AI-assisted surgical guidance, 3D modeling for pre-operative planning, and visualization tools. The company has over 8,600 da Vinci systems installed worldwide and operates in over 70 countries. In 2023, more than 2.2 million procedures were performed using da Vinci systems globally, with roughly 330,000 of these procedures performed in Europe.

organizations.name: Boston Scientific
organizations.description: Boston Scientific develops medical devices that improve the health of patients around the world. The company focuses on medical device innovation, particularly in areas like cardiovascular, endoscopy, urology, and neuromodulation. With an annual R&D investment of $1.4B billion, Boston Sci launched nearly 90 new products in 2023. The company operates multiple R&D Centers of Excellence across the United States, Ireland, Costa Rica, India and China, while also maintaining Institute for Advancing Science training centers globally. Through these facilities and initiatives, the company works closely with healthcare professionals to develop and optimize medical technologies that address unmet clinical needs.

organizations.name: Regeneron
organizations.description: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, headquartered in Tarrytown, New York, develops medicines for serious medical conditions. Its research spans eye diseases, allergic and inflammatory diseases, cancer, cardiovascular and metabolic diseases, pain, and infectious diseases. Regeneron uses its VelociSuite technologies to accelerate drug discovery and development. The Regeneron Genetics Center, one of the world's largest genetics sequencing efforts, helps identify and validate drug targets. Regeneron invested approximately $4.32 billion in R&D in 2023. The company has achieved significant success with several blockbuster drugs, including EYLEA HD and EYLEA for retinal diseases and Dupixent for inflammatory conditions, which have generated billions in annual revenue. During the pandemic, the company rapidly developed REGEN-COV (casirivimab and imdevimab), a COVID-19 antibody cocktail treatment. One Phase 3 study found that a single dose of the cocktail reduced the risk of COVID-19 by 81.6% during months 2-8 after administration.

organizations.name: Siemens Healthineers
organizations.description: Siemens Healthineers, a global medical technology company is increasingly focused on AI, precision medicine, and healthcare automation. It invests approximately €1.5 billion (8-9% of revenue) in R&D and holds about 24,000 technical intellectual property rights, including more than 15,000 patents. Its R&D spans laboratory diagnostics, imaging systems, and automated AI systems. The company's UK and Ireland R&D team collaborates with teaching hospitals and research centers to develop healthcare breakthroughs. Siemens Healthineers also operates the Siemens Clinical Laboratory (SCL) in Berkeley, California, which has provided complex testing services for over 18 years.

organizations.name: GE HealthCare
organizations.description: With $1 billion invested in R&D during 2023, GE HealthCare develops medical technology, pharmaceutical diagnostics, and imaging systems from its Chicago headquarters. The company leads FDA authorizations for AI-enabled medical devices with 58 cleared systems, including Sonic DL technology that reduces MRI scan times by 83%. Its research spans diagnostic imaging, MRI, ultrasound systems, patient monitoring equipment, contrast media, and molecular imaging agents. Recent acquisitions include Intelligent Ultrasound's clinical AI software ($51 million) and Caption Health for image guidance capabilities. The company's LOGIQ E10 ultrasound platform incorporates Verisound Digital technology, while its CareIntellect system uses AI to match oncology patients with clinical trials.

organizations.name: Edwards Lifesciences
organizations.description: Edwards Lifesciences, based in Irvine, California, makes medical devices for heart disease, and previously manufactured equipment for critical care monitoring. It completed the sale of its critical care division to BD for $4.2 billion in September 2024. Now, it's focusing exclusively on structural heart technologies. The company has developed artificial heart valves (both for surgical and transcatheter procedures), heart valve repair systems, and monitoring devices. In July 2024, the company agreed to acquire JenaValve and Endotronix for approximately $1.2 billion to expand its structural heart portfolio. Earlier in 2024, its SAPIEN valve platform demonstrated positive outcomes in clinical studies, particularly in women and patients with small annuli, and its Evoque system became the first FDA-approved transcatheter tricuspid valve replacement device.

organizations.name: Stryker
organizations.description: Stryker, a medical technology company headquartered in Portage, Michigan, specializes in orthopedic implants, medical and surgical equipment, and neurotechnology. With a 2023 R&D investment of $1.4 billion and approximately 12,900 active patents, Stryker opened its Global Technology Centre (SGTC) in Gurugram, India in 2022. Under CEO Kevin A. Lobo, Stryker has grown significantly since 2012, with revenue reaching $20.5 billion in 2023. The company has maintained an aggressive acquisition strategy, recently completing purchases of Vertos Medical, NICO Corporation, and care.ai to expand its portfolio in pain management, neurosurgery, and AI-powered healthcare technologies.

organizations.name: Amgen
organizations.description: Amgen, a biotechnology company, pioneers the use of living cells to make biologic medicines, focusing on understanding human biology and addressing serious illnesses through its expertise in human genetics, disease biology, and molecular engineering. Its second-largest R&D facility, located in San Francisco, focuses on developing treatments for cancer, inflammatory disease, and cardiometabolic disorders. Amgen scientists integrate AI and computing to enhance drug discovery, improve clinical trials, and increase efficiency, with tools like its new NVIDIA DGX SuperPOD supercomputer named Freyja installed at deCODE genetics' headquarters in Reykjavik, Iceland. Its work spans from genomics research to clinical trials, and it has successfully reduced drug development timelines by about three years through approaches. The company recently opened its most digitally manufacturing facility in New Albany, Ohio, that will create 400 full-time jobs while incorporating smart manufacturing technologies including AI, automation, and augmented reality.

organizations.name: Thermo Fisher Scientific
organizations.description: Thermo Fisher Scientific, an American multinational corporation, focuses on R&D in genomics, proteomics, and precision medicine. Its research spans life sciences, analytical instruments, specialty diagnostics, and laboratory products. The company employs approximately 95,000 employees globally, developing next-generation sequencing technologies, mass spectrometry instruments, and automation systems for diagnostic testing. Through its Precision Medicine Science Center (PMSC), Thermo Fisher advances translational omics research by providing access to technologies spanning genomic, proteomic, and metabolomic analysis. The company is committed to sustainable laboratory practices, as evidenced by its adoption of the ACT Label program to assess and improve the environmental impact of its products, with over 200 ultra-low temperature freezers already carrying the ACT label.

organizations.name: Chinese Academy of Sciences
organizations.description: The Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) is China's premier research institution, comprising 104 research institutes, 12 branch academies, 3 universities, and 11 supporting organizations across 23 provincial-level areas. CAS has a staff of 67,900, including about 56,000 professional researchers, of which approximately 22,800 are research professors or associate professors. The academy operates major scientific facilities, including the Beijing Electron Positron Collider (BEPCII) and the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Radio Telescope (FAST), which has identified over 900 new pulsars since its 2016 launch. Through its Innovation 2020 programme, CAS focuses on delivering science and technology, higher caliber talent, and superior scientific advice while serving as a think tank for S&T policy. The academy is home to over 80 percent of China's large-scale science facilities and maintains extensive international collaborations, with FAST having provided over 900 hours of observations for research teams from 15 countries since opening to the global scientific community in 2021. The organization sits atop the 2024 Nature Index rankings with a Share score of 2243.22 and 7,554 research outputs in 2023, showing a 6.3% increase from 2022. This places it significantly ahead of the second-ranked Harvard University (Share: 1143.43) and third-ranked Max Planck Society (Share: 642.83).

organizations.name: Max Planck Society
organizations.description: The Max Planck Society is Germany's premier non-university research organization, operating 84 institutes dedicated to basic research across the natural sciences, life sciences, social sciences, and the humanities. Functioning as a non-profit association of German research institutes, the Society boasts a notable record, including 31 Nobel laureates since its foundation (including its predecessor institution) and over 13,000 publications annually in scientific journals. With an annual budget of approximately €1.8 billion, the Society employs around 17,000 permanent staff, including 5,470 scientists, plus around 4,600 non-tenured scientists and guests. Primarily funded through federal and state sources, it maintains an international presence with five foreign institutions and 17 Max Planck Centers in partnership with international collaborators.

featuredContent.title: Max Planck Institute for Brain Research
featuredContent.description: This institute focuses on understanding the neural circuits underlying cognitive functions such as perception, decision-making, and memory. It houses several specialized labs, including the Decision and Awareness Group, which investigates the neural mechanisms of conscious and unconscious decision-making.

images.caption: Image for Max Planck Institute for Brain Research
images.credit: Image courtesy of Max Planck Society

featuredContent.title: Human Brain Project
featuredContent.description: The Human Brain Project is a large-scale, collaborative research initiative funded by the European Union. It aims to develop a comprehensive, multi-scale understanding of the human brain and its diseases, as well as create brain-inspired computing technologies. Several Max Planck Institutes, including the Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics, are involved in this project.

images.caption: Image for Human Brain Project
images.credit: Image courtesy of Max Planck Society

organizations.name: Weizmann Institute of Science
organizations.description: The Weizmann Institute of Science, a multidisciplinary research institution located in Rehovot, Israel, conducts research in the natural and exact sciences. With 250 experimental and theoretical research groups across five faculties—Biology, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Mathematics and Computer Science, and Physics—the institute's research spans fields from cancer immunotherapy to particle physics. The institute continues to be known for research in areas including neuroscience, nanotechnology, alternative energy, disease treatment, and environmental protection.

organizations.name: Indian Institute of Science Bangalore
organizations.description: The Indian Institute of Science (IISc) Bangalore, established in 1909, is India's premier institute for research and education across science, engineering, design, and management disciplines. With over 42 departments and centers organized into six academic divisions (Biological Sciences, Chemical Sciences, Electrical/Electronics/Computer Science, Interdisciplinary Sciences, Mechanical Sciences, and Physical & Mathematical Sciences), IISc fosters research and innovation. The institute occupies a 400-acre campus in Bangalore and was founded with active support from Jamsetji Nusserwanji Tata, to its local name as the 'Tata Institute.' IISc was granted deemed university status in 1958 and recognized as an Institute of Eminence in 2018. The institute actively promotes intellectual property development through its Office of IPTeL, which facilitates patent filing and technology licensing to benefit both the institute and society.

organizations.name: SRI International
organizations.description: Founded in 1946 as Stanford Research Institute, SRI International is a Menlo Park-based nonprofit research and development organization conducting over 500 R&D projects annually and holding more than 4,000 patents. Independent since 1970, SRI's key research areas include biomedical sciences, chemistry and materials, computing, Earth and space systems, economic development, education and learning, energy and environmental technology, security and national defense, as well as sensing and devices. SRI has launched more than 60 spin-off companies with a total market capitalization exceeding $20 billion, including innovations like Siri, the DaVinci surgical robot, and developments in internet technology through ARPAnet. With approximately 1,500 researchers and professional staff across multiple U.S. locations and Tokyo, SRI collaborates with government and commercial customers to transition technologies from laboratory to marketplace, reinvesting revenue from research and commercialization activities back into its capabilities, facilities and staff.

organizations.name: Howard Hughes Medical Institute
organizations.description: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute (HHMI) focuses on biomedical research and science education through major financial commitments, including a $2 billion investment over 10 years for diversity and inclusion initiatives, a $500 million investment in AI-powered life sciences research, and over $300 million to support 26 new investigators in 2024. HHMI operates the Janelia Research Campus, which specializes in neuroscience and imaging technology development. It provides investigators with approximately $11 million each over seven-year renewable terms. HHMI invests in science education, diversity initiatives, and research through programs like AI@HHMI and various fellowship programs. A total of 34 current or former HHMI scientists have won Nobel Prizes, with their to discoveries in areas like click chemistry and sensory receptors.

organizations.name: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique
organizations.description: The French National Centre for Scientific Research (CNRS), Europe's largest fundamental science agency, conducts basic research across all scientific disciplines through its ten institutes and over 1,000 laboratories in France. Its interdisciplinary approach addresses global challenges through collaborations with public sector, social, and economic stakeholders. CNRS has implemented six major societal challenges, including climate change and artificial intelligence. With an annual budget of €3.7 billion and 31,876 staff (23,873 permanent), including 11,076 permanent researchers, CNRS advances scientific knowledge and technology while maintaining strong international partnerships through its offices in key global scientific hubs like Melbourne, Brussels, Washington, Rio de Janeiro, Tokyo, Beijing, Singapore, New Delhi, and Pretoria.

featuredContent.title: ITER
featuredContent.description: ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor) is a major international collaboration involving CNRS and partners from 35 countries to build and operate the world's largest tokamak nuclear fusion reactor. The goal is to demonstrate the feasibility of fusion power as a safe, sustainable, and virtually limitless energy source.

organizations.name: National Institutes of Health
organizations.description: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) is the primary U.S. government agency for biomedical and public health research and the largest public funder of biomedical research in the world. The NIH conducts research through its Intramural Research Program and provides major biomedical research funding to non-NIH research facilities through its Extramural Research Program. With an annual budget of approximately $48 billion, the NIH invests in advancing medical discoveries that improve health and save lives. The organization comprises 27 separate institutes and centers, each focusing on specific areas of biomedical research, diseases, or body systems.

organizations.name: RIKEN
organizations.description: RRIKEN, Japan's largest research organization, operates a network of research centers focusing on various scientific disciplines. Founded in 1917, RIKEN's research spans brain science, quantum computing, and sustainable resource science. It houses facilities like the SPring-8 synchrotron radiation facility and the Fugaku supercomputer, enabling research in physics, chemistry, biology, and computational science. RIKEN promotes interdisciplinary collaboration and innovation in areas like genomics, AI research, and stem cell studies. Operating with an annual budget of ¥100 billion (US$750 million) as of FY2023, RIKEN maintains research partnerships with 485 partners worldwide, demonstrating its role in R&D leadership.

featuredContent.title: Fugaku Supercomputer
featuredContent.description: Fugaku is a supercomputer developed by RIKEN and Fujitsu, which became the world's fastest supercomputer in 2020. It is used for various research applications, including climate modeling, drug discovery, and quantum physics simulations.

organizations.name: Scripps Research Institute
organizations.description: Scripps Research, a nonprofit American medical research institute founded in 1924, focuses on biomedical sciences and chemistry, accelerating drug development through its Calibr-Skaggs Institute for Innovative Medicines. With more than 170 laboratories and 2,100 scientists and staff, the institute's research spans chemistry, immunology, neuroscience, and computational biology. Scripps Research has produced 15+ FDA-approved therapeutics and over 1,100 patents. Scripps Research is distinct from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, which is part of UCSD and was once called the Scripps Institution for Biological Research. The institute has consistently ranked competitively in the Nature Index.

organizations.name: National Research Council of Italy
organizations.description: The National Research Council (CNR) is Italy's largest public research institution, employing over 8,000 staff members, with more than half being researchers and technologists, plus approximately 4,000 young researchers engaged in postgraduate studies. CNR's multidisciplinary research spans across seven departments including biomedical sciences, physical sciences, earth and environmental sciences, chemical sciences, engineering and ICT, agricultural sciences, and humanities. The organization actively promotes international collaborations, and notably, registered Italy's first internet domain (cnr.it) in December 1987.

organizations.name: Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas
organizations.description: The Spanish National Research Council (CSIC), Spain's largest public research institution and the third largest in Europe, operates under the Spanish Ministry of Economy and Competitiveness through the Secretary of State for Research, Development and Innovation, fostering scientific and technological progress. Its research is structured around three Global Areas: Society, Life, and Matter (Materia), with four connecting axes (SV, SM, VM, SVM) supporting interdisciplinary work. CSIC's 120 research institutes and centers conduct research ranging from basic research to technological development. Its Interdisciplinary Thematic Platforms (PTIs) are oriented toward resolving major global challenges with high social and scientific impact. With over 10,000 staff members, including nearly 4,000 staff researchers, CSIC generates approximately 20% of Spain's scientific production and manages the country's most complete and extensive network of specialist libraries.

organizations.name: Korea Institute of Science and Technology
organizations.description: Founded in 1966 as South Korea's first multi-disciplinary scientific research institute, the Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) tackles national and social challenges through research across diverse divisions, including Brain Science, Biomedical Research, Future Convergence, and National Agenda Research Division. These divisions house specialized centers focused on areas like neuroscience, functional connectomics, and biomicrosystems within the Brain Science Institute. KIST's recent breakthroughs include quantum error correction and AI-based wearable muscle-assistance robotics. Beyond its main campus, KIST operates regional branches in Gangneung (established 2003) and Jeonbuk (established 2008), and maintains international presence through KIST Europe in Saarbruecken, Germany (established 1996) and the Indo-Korea Science and Technology Center in Bengaluru, India (established 2010).

organizations.name: Harvard University
organizations.description: Harvard University operates research programs across multiple disciplines. The Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering, established in 2009, develops nature-inspired technologies for healthcare and sustainability, with a track record of patents and startup formations. Harvard's sustainability projects include the Weld Hill Solar Project at the Arboretum and HouseZero, an energy-positive building converted from a pre-1940s structure. The university has set targets to be fossil-fuel-neutral by 2026 and fossil-fuel-free by 2050. Recent initiatives include the Generative AI Research Program for summer 2024 student projects and a new AI in Medicine PhD track at Harvard Medical School starting fall 2024, along with resources for AI pedagogy through the AI Pedagogy Project. Harvard University ranks second in the 2024 Nature Index rankings with a Share score of 1143.43 and 3,763 research outputs in 2023. While showing a slight decrease of -3.1% from 2022, it maintains its position as the highest-ranked U.S. institution, significantly ahead of other American universities like MIT (ranked 14th with Share: 484.86) and Stanford (ranked 15th with Share: 474.13).

featuredContent.title: Blue Brain Project
featuredContent.description: The Blue Brain Project is a pioneering initiative aimed at creating a biologically detailed digital reconstruction and simulation of the rodent brain. The project aims to advance our understanding of the brain's structure and function, and ultimately contribute to the development of new treatments for neurological disorders.

organizations.name: University of California, Berkeley
organizations.description: UC Berkeley, a public research university, maintains extensive research partnerships, with the Berkeley Lab-UC partnership being among the most productive integrations of a national laboratory with a major research university. The university's research ecosystem includes numerous centers and institutes, from the Berkeley Quantum Information and Computation Center to the recently announced Berkeley Space Center at NASA Ames, which will create a 36-acre innovation hub for aeronautics, astronautics, quantum computing, and climate studies. Through partnerships like the Joint Bioenergy Institute (JBEI), Berkeley combines expertise from multiple national laboratories and academic institutions to accelerate scientific discovery. The university's interdisciplinary approach extends across various fields, with research facilities and centers focusing on everything from quantum computing and space robotics to biomanufacturing and environmental studies. The university is expanding its research footprint, as evidenced by its $2 billion joint venture with NASA Ames, which will provide 130,000 square meters of research and development facilities and create new opportunities for students, faculty, and industry collaboration.

featuredContent.title: CRISPR Gene Editing
featuredContent.description: UC Berkeley researchers, including Jennifer Doudna, have made significant contributions to the development and understanding of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technology, a revolutionary tool for editing genomes with wide-ranging applications in fields like medicine, agriculture, and basic research.

organizations.name: Nanyang Technological University
organizations.description: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) focuses on interdisciplinary research and innovation through its numerous research institutes and centers. Its research spans multiple disciplines, including AI, sustainability, healthcare technologies, high-performance materials, biomedical engineering, clean energy, and nanotechnology. NTU supports entrepreneurship and innovation through initiatives like the NTU Innovation Port and NTU I&E program, which have successfully incubated over 330 startups and licensed more than 780 intellectual properties. The university is committed to commercializing research, with its portfolio of spin-off companies reaching a combined valuation exceeding SG$800 million and growing at roughly 10% annually.

organizations.name: Technical University of Denmark
organizations.description: DTU, founded in 1829 by H.C. Ørsted, the discoverer of electromagnetism, is an internationally renowned technical university modeled after France's École Polytechnique. As a technical institution in Europe, DTU operates research facilities and specialized laboratories across multiple disciplines. The university excels in diverse fields including sustainable technologies, biotechnology, wind energy systems, health technology, and chemical engineering, maintaining strong collaborations with industry partners and providing scientific consultancy. Through its research divisions and centers, DTU focuses on developing practical technologies for societal challenges while fostering innovation and technological advancement.

organizations.name: Imperial College London
organizations.description: Imperial College London, a public research university founded in 1907, focuses on science, engineering, medicine, and business. Its research labs and facilities include the Adaptive and Intelligent Robotics Lab, Aerial Robotics Lab, Biomechanics Lab, and the Energy Futures Lab. The institution translates research into commercial applications and fosters entrepreneurship. Additionally, Imperial is consistently ranked among the top universities globally, achieving sixth place in the QS World University Rankings 2024 and second place in 2025.

organizations.name: École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne
organizations.description: The École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), a public research university in Switzerland founded in 1853 as École Spéciale de Lausanne, operates more than 350 laboratories and research groups, conducting research in fields ranging from information and communication technologies to life sciences and engineering. The EPFL+ECAL Lab, established in 2007, combines academic research, artistic creativity, and cultural understanding through a transdisciplinary team of designers, engineers, and psychologists. EPFL collaborates extensively with industry partners and academic institutions, maintaining over 150 international exchange and double degree agreements with universities worldwide.

organizations.name: California Institute of Technology
organizations.description: Caltech, a private research university in Pasadena, California, is well-regarded for its focus on the physical sciences and engineering. The institute manages more than 50 research centers and institutes, fostering cross-disciplinary research across various fields such as planetary science, quantum science, and bioinformatics. Among the facilities it operates are the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) for NASA, the Seismological Laboratory, and a global network of astronomical observatories, including the Palomar and W. M. Keck Observatories. Additionally, Caltech co-manages the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO). Approximately 90% of Caltech's undergraduate students participate in research, taking advantage of the university's 3:1 student-to-faculty ratio.

organizations.name: Princeton University
organizations.description: Princeton University is heavily involved in interdisciplinary research, especially in areas such as quantum science, climate modeling, and cancer research. For instance, Princeton's role in quantum science and engineering has grown with initiatives like the Co-design Center for Quantum Advantage, which brings together 24 institutions to advance quantum technologies. The university has also collaborated with institutions such as the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory to tackle climate modeling, and expanded its cancer research through the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, focusing on metabolism in cancer prevention and treatment.

organizations.name: Georgia Institute of Technology
organizations.description: Georgia Tech, an R1 doctoral university, boasts a robust research program encompassing areas like artificial intelligence, national security, and healthcare innovation. Its applied research arm, the Georgia Tech Research Institute (GTRI), plays a vital role in national defense and technological progress. GTRI employs over 3,000 people across eight laboratories, with its headquarters in Midtown Atlanta and more than 20 field offices across the United States. GTRI's interdisciplinary research spans diverse fields including cybersecurity, electronic warfare, autonomous systems, electromagnetics, and materials technology.

organizations.name: KU Leuven
organizations.description: KU Leuven, a research-intensive university, operates through multiple interdisciplinary institutes focusing on areas like additive manufacturing, digital society, and health sciences. The university reported a research expenditure of €739.9 million in 2023, with 81.1% coming from external sources, including 45.1% from regional/national funders, 8.6% from European funding, and 27.4% from industrial contracts. Through KU Leuven Research & Development (LRD), the university has launched 151 spin-off companies since its inception and generated €150 million in licensing revenue in 2022. The university's research excellence is demonstrated by its leadership in Horizon Europe, where it has secured €247 million in grants across 418 projects, making it the top grant recipient among higher education institutions. Since 2007, KU Leuven has hosted 153 ERC grants, establishing itself as a premier destination for researchers.

organizations.name: Yaskawa Electric
organizations.description: Yaskawa Electric Corporation, established in 1915 by Daigorou Yasukawa in Kurosaki, Kitakyushu City, is a prominent leader in industrial automation and robotics, known for the concept of 'mechatronics' through their engineer Tetsuro Mori in 1969. The company specializes in AC drives, servo drives, industrial robots, and machine controllers, with significant focus on research and development. Through their i³-Mechatronics initiative, they integrate IoT, AI, and automation technologies for smart manufacturing systems. The company has expanded its global presence, including a recent $200 million investment in new manufacturing facilities in Wisconsin and Ohio, expected to employ about 1,750 workers. In 2024, they completed a 185,000-square-foot expansion of their Miamisburg, Ohio headquarters, nearly doubling their production space to meet growing automation industry demands.

organizations.name: Boston Dynamics
organizations.description: Boston Dynamics, founded in 1992 as an MIT spin-off, develops robots specializing in dynamic mobility and locomotion. The company focuses on creating robots that mimic human and animal movements through biomimetic design, AI integration, and continuous innovation, with notable products including Spot, Atlas, and Stretch. The company invests heavily in software development, particularly in perception, navigation, and autonomous systems. In 2022, Hyundai Motor Group and Boston Dynamics launched the Boston Dynamics AI Institute with a $400 million investment to advance research in athletic AI, cognitive AI, and organic hardware design. After its acquisition by Hyundai Motor Group in 2021, Boston Dynamics continues to expand commercial applications of its robotics technology.

organizations.name: Fanuc
organizations.description: Founded in 1956, FANUC Corporation is a global leader in factory automation, robotics, and CNC systems, achieving a significant milestone in August 2023 with the shipment of its one-millionth industrial robot. Operating under its 'one FANUC' philosophy, the company integrates its Factory Automation (FA), ROBOT, and ROBOMACHINE divisions with a focus on complete service. FANUC has consistently pursued factory automation since its founding, developing everything from CNC systems and servo motors to industrial robots and robomachines. With a substantial global presence, FANUC operates through a network of more than 270 service locations in over 100 countries worldwide.

organizations.name: KUKA
organizations.description: KUKA AG, founded in 1898 as an acetylene plant by Johann Josef Keller and Jakob Knappich in Augsburg, Germany, has evolved into a manufacturer of industrial robots and factory automation systems. The company conducts extensive R&D and maintains partnerships with universities and research institutes worldwide. Through its Innovation Management division and Business Innovation Lab, KUKA drives technological progress in automation and robotics, with a particular focus on Industry 4.0 systems and smart manufacturing. As part of the Midea Group since 2016, KUKA continues to pioneer developments in robotic automation, cloud-based services, and digital production technologies.

organizations.name: Universal Robots
organizations.description: Founded in 2005 by Esben Østergaard, Kasper Støy, and Kristian Kassow, Universal Robots (UR) specializes in collaborative robots (cobots) designed for safe human-robot interaction in shared workspaces. UR's cobots are known for their user-friendly programming interface and versatility. The company's UR+ ecosystem provides a platform for third-party developers to create certified compatible accessories and software systems. UR's e-Series cobots feature built-in force/torque sensors and repeatability of up to 30 microns for precise tasks like assembly and quality inspection. These cobots are deployed across diverse industries, from automotive and electronics to food processing, with applications including welding, machine tending, palletizing, and quality control. Since 2015, Universal Robots has been owned by Teradyne and maintains its position as a market leader in the collaborative robotics sector.

organizations.name: iRobot
organizations.description: iRobot Corporation, founded in 1990 as IS Robotics, is an innovator in consumer robotics, particularly known for its Roomba vacuum and Braava mopping robots. Holding over 1,915 patents and having sold more than 50 million robots globally, iRobot continues to advance home robotics through technologies like mapping, navigation, and AI, supporting autonomous operation in complex environments. While the company previously worked on military and marine robotics, it sold its defense division in 2016 to focus primarily on the consumer market. Focusing on seamless human-robot interaction, iRobot's development of intelligent features and mapping capabilities through its iRobot OS reinforces its position as a pioneer in developing practical robots for everyday use.

organizations.name: SoftBank Group
organizations.description: SoftBank Group is advancing its focus on AI and robotics through multiple strategic initiatives. Through its Digital Twin Campus Lab collaboration with Keio Research Institute at SFC, it is developing next-generation information infrastructure and autonomous vehicle technologies. The company has also launched SB Intuitions, a subsidiary dedicated to developing Japanese-specific large language models (LLMs) using a computing platform powered by over 2,000 NVIDIA GPUs. The company plans to complete development of 350 billion-parameter LLMs by 2024, aiming to create AI systems specifically tailored to Japanese language, business practices, and culture.

organizations.name: SZ DJI Technology Co., Ltd.
organizations.description: DJI, headquartered in Shenzhen, dominates the global consumer drone market, controlling approximately 70% of market share. Its UAVs are used across diverse industries, from filmmaking and agriculture to disaster relief, showcasing DJI's leadership in drone technology and AI integration. Through partnerships with institutions like UNSW Sydney and the Polytechnic University of Turin, DJI drives innovation in drone education and research. Its agricultural drones have treated over 500 million hectares of farmland globally, while its disaster relief programs equip first responders with drone technology for emergency response and recovery efforts. DJI's enterprise systems have contributed to at least 278 successful rescue operations worldwide, demonstrating the practical impact of its technology.

organizations.name: Omron Robotics and Safety Technologies
organizations.description: Omron Robotics and Safety Technologies is advancing in robotics and automation through strategic partnerships and cognitive robotics development. Their focus includes the integration of AI and sensor technologies for manufacturing automation, with the recent partnership with Neura Robotics marking a significant step in this direction. The 'i-Automation' initiative drives their manufacturing innovation through intelligent, integrated, and interactive automation technologies, while their 'Shaping the Future 2030' vision addresses three key social issues: carbon neutrality, realization of a digital society, and extension of healthy life expectancies. These initiatives aim to create sustainable automation systems that balance environmental concerns with worker satisfaction while advancing manufacturing capabilities.

organizations.name: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company
organizations.description: TSMC, the world's largest dedicated semiconductor foundry, is headquartered in Hsinchu Science Park, Taiwan. Founded in 1987 by Morris Chang, TSMC manufactures chips for over 500 customers and produces nearly 12,000 different products. Its R&D organization focuses on developing -edge process technologies at 2-nanometer and beyond, while also conducting exploratory research in novel materials and transistor structures. In 2023, TSMC inaugurated a new global R&D Center in Hsinchu that houses over 7,000 researchers and serves as the company's primary hub for semiconductor technology innovation.

organizations.name: Advanced Micro Devices
organizations.description: AMD, reporting $22.7 billion in 2023 revenue, develops advanced processors and graphics technologies through its Research and Advanced Development (RAD) division, investing $5.9 billion in R&D during 2023—a 17% increase focused on AI capabilities. The company's research spans high-performance computing, machine learning, and specialized processors, with recent acquisitions of Mipsology SAS and Nod, Inc. strengthening its AI software portfolio. AMD's data center segment produces EPYC processors and Instinct GPUs for AI workloads and supercomputing, while its gaming division provides custom chips for platforms including PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S. With approximately 26,000 employees globally, AMD has expanded beyond traditional CPU and GPU architectures to focus on AI training and inference applications for cloud, edge, and intelligent endpoints.

organizations.name: NXP Semiconductors NV
organizations.description: NXP Semiconductors, a Dutch semiconductor manufacturing and design company, focuses its R&D efforts on automotive, industrial & IoT, mobile, and communication infrastructure technologies. Headquartered in Eindhoven, Netherlands, NXP has invested significantly in expanding its R&D capabilities, notably with facilities in Austin, Texas. The NXP Advanced Manufacturing Lab at Austin Community College provides hands-on STEM education and training for both adult and high school students, fostering local technical talent in semiconductor manufacturing. The Smart Home Innovation Lab in Austin, designed as a fully furnished home environment, enables engineers to test and develop new smart home technologies in collaboration with partners like Honeywell.

organizations.name: SK Group
organizations.description: SK Group, a South Korean conglomerate, includes SK hynix, the world's third-largest semiconductor manufacturer and second-largest memory chip maker in South Korea after Samsung Electronics. The group's R&D focuses primarily on semiconductors, energy, chemicals, and telecommunications, with additional ventures in life sciences and pharmaceuticals. SK hynix specializes in memory technology, particularly high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips where it is the dominant global supplier, along with DRAM and NAND flash memory products. Subsidiaries like SK Life Science and SK bioscience operate in different therapeutic areas - SK Life Science focuses on CNS disorders and oncology drug development, while SK bioscience specializes in vaccine development and manufacturing.

organizations.name: Applied Materials
organizations.description: With a consistently growint R&D budget, Applied Materials specializes in semiconductor and display technologies, providing materials engineering technologies used in the production of most new chips and displays worldwide. The company spent more than $3 billion on R&D in 2023, focusing on atomic-level materials modification and scalable industrial implementation through several corefacilities, including the Maydan Technology Center, which employs more than 500 engineers and houses 120 process tools for testing and development; the Materials Engineering Technology Accelerator (META) Center in Albany, which develops new chipmaking materials; and the Advanced Packaging Development Center, which conducts research on wafer-level packaging. Recently, Applied Materials announced the EPIC Center, intended to be the world's largest facility for collaborative semiconductor R&D, and established a joint laboratory with A*STAR in Singapore for semiconductor equipment development. Additionally, the company is addressing sustainability through its Net Zero 2040 Playbook. It aims to significantly reduce carbon emissions from the semiconductor industry, which currently accounts for over 99% of its carbon footprint.

organizations.name: Texas Instruments
organizations.description: Texas Instruments Incorporated (TI) is a global semiconductor design and manufacturing company headquartered in Dallas, Texas, specializing in analog ICs and embedded processors. The company operates a network of 15 manufacturing sites and is the largest U.S. analog and embedded processing semiconductor manufacturer. TI supports academic research through various initiatives, including the 1,100-square-foot Texas Instruments Innovation Lab at UTDesign Studio and major investments in educational facilities. The company maintains TI Precision Labs (TIPL), a comprehensive online classroom for analog signal chain and embedded processing designers, offering on-demand courses covering topics from foundational knowledge to concepts across multiple technology domains.

organizations.name: ASM International
organizations.description: ASM International, founded in 1964 in the Netherlands, specializes in providing equipment for the semiconductor industry, focusing primarily on wafer processing technologies. A key area of their expertise is Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD), where they hold a 55% global market share. ALD is a highly controlled process for creating ultra-thin films used in semiconductor manufacturing, allowing for precise layering at the atomic scale, which is essential for producing modern chips with smaller and more efficient transistors. ASM also develops tools for epitaxy, plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD), and vertical furnace systems. With R&D centers in seven countries, they focus on developing next-generation materials and processes that support the continuous scaling of semiconductor devices.

organizations.name: Marvell Technology
organizations.description: Marvell Technology, reporting $1.16 billion in Q1 2025 revenue, develops semiconductor solutions for data infrastructure, with data center revenue growing 87% year-over-year driven by AI initiatives. The Santa Clara-based company invests heavily in research across five key markets: data center, enterprise networking, carrier infrastructure, consumer, and automotive/industrial. Its data center segment, representing 70% of revenue, focuses on cloud AI systems, ethernet switching, and storage networks. Marvell's custom AI programs complement its electro-optics business, while its enterprise division develops technologies for campus networking and security appliances. Operating as a fabless semiconductor company, Marvell maintains a non-GAAP R&D investment of $455 million quarterly, developing next-generation solutions for cloud computing, 5G infrastructure, and automotive applications.

organizations.name: Microchip Technology
organizations.description: Microchip Technology, headquartered in Chandler, Arizona, is a leader in embedded control technologies, focusing heavily on microcontroller, analog, and memory technologies. One of its specialized areas includes atomic frequency standards, which are crucial for timekeeping applications globally. The company produces high-precision cesium atomic clocks like the 5071A and 5071B, which are used in timekeeping and synchronization across various industries including telecommunications, data centers, metrology, aviation, and defense. These clocks offer exceptional accuracy, with the 5071B providing absolute frequency accuracy of 5E-13 over all specified environmental conditions and maintaining 100 ns holdover for more than two months during GNSS signal disruptions. In addition to atomic clocks, Microchip's timing technologies include products that support modern synchronization protocols like GNSS-based timing and IEEE 1588 Precise Time Protocol (PTP), ensuring strong and resilient timing for critical infrastructures. The claims about R&D facilities and square footage should be removed as they are not supported by the search results.

organizations.name: Broadcom
organizations.description: Broadcom Inc., a major technology company headquartered in Palo Alto, California, designs and supplies semiconductor and infrastructure software products. With a diverse portfolio serving data centers, networking, and wireless communications, among other markets, approximately 79% of its revenue comes from semiconductor products and 21% from infrastructure software. Broadcom emphasizes strategic growth through acquisitions, notably completing its $61 billion purchase of VMware in late 2023 and previously acquiring CA Technologies. In research and development, Broadcom has partnered with Caltech to establish the Broadcom Quantum Laboratory, furthering quantum science research. Looking ahead, the company actively prepares for the advent of quantum computing by developing crypto-agile products and following NIST guidance to address future security challenges. For fiscal year 2023, the company's total net revenue was $35.82 billion, with $27.89 billion from products and $7.93 billion from subscriptions and services. Research and development expenses amounted to $5.25 billion, accounting for 15% of the net revenue, a slight increase from the previous year's $4.92 billion.

organizations.name: Helmholtz Association of German Research Centres
organizations.description: Germany's largest scientific organization, the Helmholtz Association comprises 18 scientific-technical and biological-medical research centers with approximately 46,000 employees. It addresses challenges in science, society, and industry through research and development across six major research fields. The association develops and operates unique research infrastructures. Examples include the world's most powerful X-ray laser, research vessels, supercomputers, and particle accelerators, which thousands of international researchers use annually.

organizations.name: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
organizations.description: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) is a prestigious research institution established in 1952 as a branch of the University of California's Radiation Laboratory. The laboratory, managed by Lawrence Livermore National Security, LLC for the Department of Energy's National Nuclear Security Administration, has earned 179 R&D 100 awards since 1978. With a workforce of more than 8,500 scientists, engineers, and support staff, LLNL conducts research across multiple critical areas, including nuclear weapons science, nonproliferation, high-performance computing, fusion energy, and biological science. The facility encompasses a one-square-mile main site in Livermore, California, and an 11-square-mile remote experimental test site known as Site 300 near Tracy. Under the leadership of Director Kim Budil, LLNL continues to advance scientific innovation, with particular strengths in stockpile stewardship, simulation and computing, and high-energy-density science. The laboratory has been recognized as one of Glassdoor's Best Places to Work in 2024.

It fosters interdisciplinary collaboration and transfers technologies to government agencies, industry, and academia.

organizations.name: Los Alamos National Laboratory
organizations.description: Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL), located about 35 miles northwest of Santa Fe, New Mexico, is a multi-program, federally funded research and development center operated by Triad National Security, LLC for the U.S. Department of Energy's National Nuclear Security Administration. Historically renowned for developing the first atomic bomb during the Manhattan Project, LANL's primary mission is to provide scientific and engineering support to national security programs, with a focus on nuclear weapons design and production. The laboratory's research capabilities are organized into six Capability Pillars: Materials for the Future, Nuclear and Particle Futures, Integrating Information, Science, and Technology for Prediction, Science of Signatures, Weapons Systems, and Complex Natural and Engineering Systems. Additionally, LANL conducts research in energy security, developing reliable and sustainable carbon-neutral energy systems, while also performing theoretical and applied research in materials science, environmental science, and health-related studies.

organizations.name: Idaho National Laboratory
organizations.description: Idaho National Laboratory (INL), a U.S. Department of Energy multiprogram national laboratory managed by the Battelle Energy Alliance, focuses its research and development on several key areas. INL is renowned for its nuclear energy research, progress in reactor technologies, fuel cycle research, and nonproliferation, playing a central role in the DOE's Advanced Reactor Technologies (ART) Program. The laboratory also contributes to national and homeland security through research in critical infrastructure protection, cybersecurity, and technologies for defense and intelligence, operating the Cyber Core Integration Center to secure industrial control systems like power, oil, natural gas, and water from cyber threats. Furthermore, INL's energy and environment research focuses on improving energy generation, distribution, and storage, including renewable energy integration and progress in hybrid energy systems, bioenergy, and clean energy technologies. Located on an 890-square-mile desert site in southeastern Idaho, INL, established in 1949 as the National Reactor Testing Station, has a long history of nuclear energy research, including developing much of the world's current knowledge about how nuclear reactors behave.

featuredContent.title: Battelle National Biodefense Institute
featuredContent.description: Battelle Memorial Institute, founded in 1929 and headquartered in Columbus, Ohio, is the world's largest independent research and development organization. Operating as a non-profit, Battelle employs over 3,200 staff and manages an additional 29,500 employees across more than 130 global locations, conducting approximately $6.5 billion in annual R&D. The institute manages or co-manages several U.S. Department of Energy national laboratories, including Oak Ridge and Pacific Northwest, and its key business areas include laboratory management, national security, health and life sciences, and energy and environmental sciences. Recent endeavors include a $416 million award to operate the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), managing over 180 data products for ecological research, and developing critical technologies during the COVID-19 pandemic.

organizations.name: Southwest Research Institute
organizations.description: The Southwest Research Institute (SwRI), a prominent independent, non-profit R&D organization founded in 1947, occupies a 1,500-acre campus in San Antonio, Texas. Employing more than 3,100 scientists, engineers, and technical staff, SwRI provides multidisciplinary research services across diverse sectors, including aerospace, automotive, energy, and defense. Through its eleven technical divisions, covering areas like applied physics, space science, and intelligent systems, SwRI conducts over 4,000 active research projects for government and industry clients, focusing on complex problem-solving technologies that benefit both technology and human well-being. With annual revenue of nearly $844 million, SwRI demonstrates a strong commitment to community engagement and STEM education through various programs supporting future researchers.

organizations.name: General Electric Company
organizations.description: Founded in 1892 through the merger of Edison General Electric Company and Thomson-Houston Electric Company, GE completed its split into three independent companies in April 2024: GE HealthCare (separated January 2023), GE Vernova (renewable energy and power), and GE Aerospace (retaining the GE ticker symbol). GE Aerospace develops aircraft engines and systems, including the CFM RISE program targeting 20% fuel reduction. GE HealthCare focuses on medical imaging and diagnostic technology. GE Vernova's power generation technology contributes to approximately 25% of global electricity production. The separation ended GE's 132-year history as a unified company. The GE Vernova will holds 36,000 patents and patent applications across 60 countries, according to the company's website.

Recent key initiatives include a multibillion-dollar partnership with Microsoft to accelerate AI innovation, with plans to invest 300 billion yen ($2.1 billion) in GenAI and train over 50,000 professionals in AI skills. As part of its reorganization, Hitachi Vantara's systems business has been spun off into Hitachi Digital Services, while Hitachi Vantara LLC focuses on data infrastructure services. The company employs approximately 268,655 people worldwide and had revenues of 9,728.7 billion yen for fiscal year 2023.

organizations.name: Industrial Technology Research Institute
organizations.description: Founded in 1973, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has been instrumental in transforming Taiwan's economy from labor-intensive to innovation-driven. With over 6,000 outstanding employees, this non-profit R&D organization focuses on applied research and technical services, having nurtured more than 240 companies, including TSMC and UMC. ITRI's research concentrates on smart living, quality health, sustainable environment, and resilient society, with a global presence including offices in the US, Europe, and Japan. The institute has launched its 2035 Technology Strategy & Roadmap focusing on these areas while harnessing AI, cybersecurity, semiconductor, communication, and smart sensing technologies. ITRI offers comprehensive R&D collaboration services, including contract research, small-scale pilot production, process improvement, technology transfers, and IP value-added services. Through its open labs and incubators, ITRI promotes startups and entrepreneurship while actively working to speed up technological development in industries.

organizations.name: Bell Labs
organizations.description: Founded in 1925 as Bell Telephone Laboratories, Bell Labs has a rich history of innovations. From fundamental scientific discoveries like radio astronomy and the transistor to transformative communication technologies such as the first long-distance television transmission and cellular wireless systems, Bell Labs has shaped the modern world. Its contributions extend to computing with the development of the UNIX operating system, the C and C++ programming languages. Recognized with nine Nobel Prizes and four Turing Awards, Bell Labs fostered a multidisciplinary research environment that encouraged collaboration and long-term vision. Initially owned jointly by AT&T and Western Electric, the organization went through several ownership changes before becoming Nokia Bell Labs, where it continues its legacy of innovation, building upon a foundation of fundamental research and practical application.

organizations.name: Dow Chemical Company
organizations.description: Dow, a materials science company headquartered in Midland, Michigan, generated $45 billion in sales in 2023, with 40% occurring digitally. Operating in 31 countries with roughly 35,900 employees, Dow is focused on growth. In 2024, the company pursued strategic acquisitions like Circulus, a plastic waste recycler with 50,000 metric tons of annual capacity, while divesting its flexible packaging laminating adhesives business to Arkema for $150 million. Dow also won six innovation awards, launched sustainable products like EcoSense and ELECPURE, and committed to producing 3 million metric tons of circular and renewable systems annually by 2030. To achieve its goal of increasing earnings by more than $3 billion annually, Dow plans to expand alkoxylates and specialty amines capacity, develop a $6.5 billion net-zero emissions ethylene complex in Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta, and grow its recycled plastics business to generate an additional $500 million in earnings by 2030.

organizations.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology
organizations.description: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) was established on March 3, 1901, as the National Bureau of Standards, making it one of the nation's oldest physical science laboratories. It was renamed the Bureau of Standards in 1903, reverted to the National Bureau of Standards in 1934, and finally became NIST in 1988. Throughout its history, NIST has made significant contributions across multiple fields, from developing the first neon lighting for the 1904 World's Fair to creating atomic clocks and standards for DNA profiling. Today, the organization supports technologies ranging from nanoscale devices to earthquake-resistant skyscrapers and global communication networks. In recent years, NIST has expanded its focus to include emerging challenges like artificial intelligence safety standards and cybersecurity frameworks. With a fiscal year 2024 budget request of $1.6 billion, NIST continues to serve as a cornerstone of American technological innovation and industrial competitiveness.

featuredContent.title: Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology
featuredContent.description: The Center for Nanoscale Science and Technology (CNST) supports nanoscale science, engineering and technology through research and by making cutting-edge nanoscale measurement and fabrication methods widely accessible to researchers. It operates a state-of-the-art nanofabrication facility and provides researchers with access to tools and expertise for nanoscale measurement and fabrication.

organizations.name: Electric Power Research Institute
organizations.description: EPRI (Electric Power Research Institute) emerged from a critical moment in American history — the Great Northeastern Blackout of 1965, which left 30 million people without power and exposed the vulnerability of the nation's power grid. The watershed event led to Congressional hearings in the early 1970s, ultimately resulting in EPRI's establishment under the leadership of Chauncey Starr, Ph.D., who served as its first president. Today, EPRI operates from principal offices and laboratories across the U.S., including locations in Palo Alto, Charlotte, Knoxville, Washington, D.C., and Lenox. Its generation research specifically focuses on improving the flexibility, reliability, and efficiency of both fossil-fueled and renewable energy systems.
